item.title: Venezuela | Beijing will maintain support regardless of the political situation
item.description: The Chinese Government reaffirmed Friday that, regardless of what happens in Venezuela, the Asian country will continue to support Caracas in defending its sovereignty and national security. “China will continue to firmly support Venezuela in safeguarding its sovereignty, dignity and national security, regardless of how the political situation evolves,” said Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Mao Ning. The spokesperson highlighted that Beijing has maintained “solid” communication and cooperation with the Venezuelan Government and that the country “is deeply committed to deepening practical cooperation and promoting common development”. The Asian country, which has maintained close relations with Caracas in recent years, harshly condemned the United States' military intervention in Venezuela and demanded the release of former president Nicolás Maduro and his wife, Cilia Flores, who were taken to New York. The interim president of Venezuela, Delcy Rodríguez, met on Thursday with the Chinese ambassador, Lan Hu, highlighting China's “firm and consistent position in strongly condemning the serious violation of international law and Venezuelan sovereignty”, according to official Venezuelan information. North American sources cited by the ABC television network indicated that the Administration of the President of the United States, Donald Trump, informed Rodríguez that Venezuela will have to end its relations with China, Russia, Iran and Cuba as a condition for being able to extract and sell its oil.

item.title: FAOM | Praises casino subsidies, but calls for more measures
item.description: The Federation of Workers' Associations of Macau (FAOM) praised the concessionaires' option to award bonuses to workers, but called for more measures, mainly in terms of reducing long workloads. The position was taken by Choi Kam Fu, vice-president of FAOM. According to statements cited by the newspaper Ou Mun, Choi Kam Fu considered that the gaming concessionaires' bonuses reflect a policy of “sharing the fruits of development” in society, which helps workers feel valued and happy. However, the association leader warned that many concessionaire workers face long periods of work that are having a significant impact on the workers' physical and mental level. Faced with increased pressure to recover the game, Choi Kam Fu called on concessionaires to improve workers' salaries and other benefits, invest more time in training and increase the number of job openings, to meet actual needs, instead of forcing current workers to work excessively long shifts.

item.title: Health | 480 requests for support for assisted procreation received
item.description: Since the Government launched the Medically Assisted Procreation Treatment Participation Program, in December 2024, until November last year, the Health Services (SS) received 480 requests from residents, said the director of Health Services, Alvis Lo, in response to a written inquiry signed by Leong Sun Iok. In the same period of time, Alvis Lo revealed that 352 couples were referred to the Macau Union Medical Center's outpatient infertility consultation, of which “around 130 cases are able to receive the services of in vitro fertilization technique or intracytoplasmic sperm injection technique”. Regarding access to this type of health care, the director of the SS indicated that, from October 2025, these services will be available, gradually, with the aim that all eligible cases can be attended to within the first half of 2026. Alvis Lo added that “the Macau Union Medical Center has allocated 16 workers, including doctors, laboratory analysis technicians and nursing professionals, among others, to support assisted procreation services”. Currently, subsidies cover expenses for oocyte retrieval and embryo transfer in two cycles (each cycle includes an oocyte retrieval surgery and an embryo transfer). However, the SS director stressed that the program “is still in an initial phase of implementation”, but that in the future it could be reviewed after an assessment of its effectiveness.

item.title: Monte Fortress | Exhibition celebrates restoration of the Mogao Caves
item.description: From next Friday, the 16th, it will be possible to get to know more about the Mogao Caves, in Dunhuang, China, classified by UNESCO and which, over the last hundred years, have been the target of successive restoration actions, taking into account the importance of their architectural, cultural and historical heritage. The “Dunhuang Caves Restoration Centenary Exhibition” will be available at the Monte Fortress gallery From Friday the 16th, the Fortaleza do Monte gallery hosts an exhibition on one of China's great monuments, classified by UNESCO. This is the “Exhibition of the Centenary of the Restoration of the Dunhuang Caves”, more specifically the Mogao Caves. The exhibition is supported by the Cultural Institute (IC) and organized by the Macau Heritage Studies Association and the Association of Friends of Culture of Dunhuang of Macau. The inauguration takes place at 6:30 pm. According to a note released on social media by the Macau Heritage Studies Association, this exhibition aims to present to the public “the work to protect the Dunhuang caves over the last hundred years, one of the only two sites worldwide that meets all six criteria of World Cultural Heritage [by UNESCO], and is also the largest and best preserved sanctuary of Buddhist cave art in the world”. According to the same note, “since their discovery, the Mogao Caves have received great attention from the public, and, over more than a century, various efforts have been made to protect this precious heritage”. Currently, according to the association, “the conservation of the Mogao Caves has become an exemplary model for the protection of cultural heritage, serving as a reference for learning and jointly safeguarding our cultural heritage”. Great treasure According to the UNESCO portal, the Mogao Caves are located “at a strategic point along the Silk Road, at the crossroads of commercial, religious, cultural and intellectual influences”, containing 492 cells and sanctuaries, as well as sculptures and wall paintings, “which span a thousand years of Buddhist art”. "Carved into the cliffs above the Dachuan River, southeast of the Dunhuang oasis, in Gansu province, the Mogao Caves constitute the largest, most richly endowed and longest-used treasure trove of Buddhist art in the world. Its construction began in 366 AD, representing an extraordinary achievement of Buddhist art between the 4th and 14th centuries. Currently, 492 caves are preserved, housing approximately 45,000 square meters of murals and more than 2,000 painted sculptures”, UNESCO further describes. It is a heritage complex that testifies to “the evolution of Buddhist art in northwest China”, possessing “an incomparable historical value”. For UNESCO, the Mogao Caves “provide abundant visual material on diverse aspects of the politics, economy, culture, arts, religion, ethnic relations and everyday clothing of western medieval China”. The Mogao Caves were discovered in 1900, and include a library area and “tens of thousands of manuscripts and relics”, being described as “the world’s greatest discovery of ancient Eastern culture”. One of the six criteria mentioned by the Macau Heritage Studies Association is the fact that “the group of Mogao Caves represents a unique artistic achievement, both due to the organization of the space in 492 caves spread over five levels, and the creation of more than 2,000 painted sculptures and around 45,000 square meters of murals, among which there are numerous masterpieces of Chinese art”, points out UNESCO. Another criterion concerns a historical issue, namely the fact that “for a thousand years, from the period of the Northern Wei dynasty (386–534) to the Yuan dynasty of Mongol rule (1276–1386), the Mogao Caves played a decisive role in artistic exchanges between China, Central Asia and India”. Furthermore, there is a third criterion, related to the cave paintings, which “constitute an exceptional testimony to the civilizations of ancient China during the Sui, Tang and Song dynasties”. A fourth criterion is linked to the “Groats of a Thousand Buddhas”, which constitute “a notable example of a Buddhist rock art sanctuary”. The fifth criterion concerns the occupation of the caves by Buddhist monks “from the end of the 19th century until 1930”, with the “Mogao rock art group, administered by the Dunhuang Cultural Relics Research Institute, preserving the example of a traditional monastic settlement”. The sixth and final UNESCO criterion for this classification involves the caves being “strongly associated with the history of transcontinental relations and the spread of Buddhism throughout Asia”. “For centuries, the Dunhuang oasis, close to the bifurcation of the two branches of the Silk Road, benefited from the status of a transit station where not only goods were exchanged, but also ideas, as demonstrated by the Chinese, Tibetan, Sogdian, Khotan, Uyghur and even Hebrew manuscripts found in the caves”, it is described.

item.title: ONE | First public medical college will have 4,000 students
item.description: The Faculty of Medicine is part of the new campus of the University of Macau, under construction since December 12, in the Guangdong-Macao In-depth Cooperation Zone The University of Macau (UM) announced that the first faculty of medicine, created in collaboration with the University of Lisbon (ULisboa), will have 4,000 students. In a statement, UM said that the future Faculty of Medicine will be created through the expansion of the current Faculty of Health Sciences, with the aim of “becoming a world-class medical school”. The new faculty will include departments of Pharmaceutical Sciences and Nutrition, Dental Medicine and Clinical Medicine, the latter with a joint program developed with ULisboa, UM said on Friday. “Building on the Faculty of Medicine’s experience in international joint programs, UM will expand collaborative programs with world-renowned universities in the areas of information science, engineering and design,” the note added. The university is committed to attracting international students, recruiting high-level talent for teaching and research, building international platforms for scientific and technological exchange, hosting major international conferences and supporting the development of academic journals. The Faculty of Medicine is part of the new UM campus, whose construction began on December 12, in the Guangdong-Macao Deep Cooperation Zone, on the neighboring island of Montanha. Three-year construction The new campus will occupy 376,000 square meters in the special economic zone and construction is expected to take three years, with partial opening scheduled for 2028 and construction completion in 2029. Four new faculties will be created in Hengqin, including Information Sciences, Design and Engineering, as well as Macau's first public medical faculty. The Macau University of Science and Technology, a private institution, has had a Faculty of Health Sciences since 2008, officially renamed the Faculty of Medicine in 2019. In June, the director of the Faculty of Medicine at ULisboa told Lusa that doctors trained at the future Faculty of Medicine at UM will also be able to practice in Portugal. ULisboa is collaborating with UM to create a curriculum with a structure “close to the structure” of courses at the Portuguese institution, said Luís Graça. In December, the vice-rector of UM, Rui Martins, said that the new campus will focus on "'dual degrees' [courses in co-tutelship] with foreign universities. Medicine is already with Lisbon and now we are defining it for the other faculties". The new campus in Hengqin should allow UM to expand from its current 15,000 students to a maximum of 25,000 students, highlighted the vice-rector for Global Affairs, in an interview with the Portuguese-language channel of local public television TDM.

item.title: Windsor Arch | Court refuses confiscation of 264 apartments
item.description: The housing units were built outside the project and correspond to almost 30 percent of the built area. Instead of accepting the confiscation, the TJB held William Kuan Wai Lam, Ng Kei Nin and Ng Lap Seng responsible for paying the value of the apartments to the Macao SAR The Base Judicial Court (TJB) refused the confiscation of 264 of the 265 apartments in the Windsor Arch housing complex that were in the process of being declared property of the Macao SAR. The information was provided by Canal Macau on Friday. According to information disseminated, the TJB refused to confiscate the 264 units, which had since been sold, as it understood that the fairest option was for some of those convicted in the Public Works case to pay the value of the apartments to Macao. The court identified convicts William Kuan Wai Lam, Ng Kei Nin and Ng Lap Seng as responsible for the payments, the amount of which will only be defined later, during the execution process. The apartments are at the center of the controversy because they were built “outside the project area”, despite representing practically 30 percent of the entire housing project. However, when the Ou Mun newspaper first-hand reported the intention to proceed with the confiscation of the apartments, it also indicated that the affected owners, who claimed to be unaware of the illegalities, had resorted to legal advice to avoid losing the apartments. Currently, Ng Lap Seng and Ng Kei Lin, son of the first businessman, are free, after having served, in the context of the Public Works case, prison sentences of four and a half and two years, respectively. Wiliam Kuan is still in Coloane Prison, serving a sentence of five years and six months, but is expected to be released later this year. Public Works Case The Windsor Arch project came under judicial scrutiny as part of the case that resulted in the sentencing of Jaime Carion and Li Canfeng, former directors of Public Works, to prison sentences. According to the Public Prosecutor's Office's indictment, the government officials will have received patrimonial advantages, through their families, to approve construction licenses for different projects, including the Windsor Arch, promoted by William Kuan and Ng Lap Seng. Jaime Carion facilitated the approval of the project, whose characteristics, dimensions and height differed from those stipulated in the concession contract and in the urban plans for the area. In this case, the MP alleged that Carion acted in concert with his, at the time, number two at DSSOPT, Li Canfeng, pressuring technicians from the services they directed to give the green light to several proposed changes to the original project. Carion was tried in absentia and sentenced to 16 years in prison, for six crimes of money laundering and five crimes of passive corruption for an illicit act. Li Canfeng was sentenced to 17 years in prison for five crimes of passive corruption for an illicit act, four of money laundering, one of forgery of documents, one of abuse of power and four of inaccurate information.

item.title: Metro | Station opened for just over a year will have new coverage
item.description: The Government and the Macau Light Rail Society justified the intervention at Lótus Station with the need to replace the roof that was damaged due to the passage of a typhoon The Lótus Light Rail Station will undergo renovation work to replace the roof, starting today. The announcement was made on Friday, through a joint statement from the Traffic Affairs Services Department (DSAT) and the Macau Light Rail Company (MLM). In operation since December 2024, just over a year ago, the works were justified by the damage suffered by the roof: “The Sociedade do Metro Ligeiro de Macau, S.A. (MLM) will begin, on January 12th, after the necessary coordination, the work to replace the roof system of the Lotus Station on the Taipa Line, which was previously damaged due to the passage of a typhoon”, it was announced. “The work will include the complete replacement of the station's covering system and the platform's false ceiling, among other works, within a period of 120 working days, in order to improve the waiting environment”, it was added. During the works “parts of the platform will be closed in phases, and the metro will run on the Taipa Line with two-car trains”. However, MLM promises that “during periods of greater affluence, the frequency [of circulation] will be increased to ensure passenger travel needs”. The cost of the intervention at the station, which opened just over a year ago, was not revealed. Road Circulation The impacts of replacing the roof are not limited to the constraints on the circulation of the Light Rail and will also affect the roads close to the station. “On the section of Estrada Flor de Lótus, next to the Lótus Station of the Light Metro (towards the Ponte Flor de Lótus), traffic will be restricted, and the pedestrian passage under the station will be temporarily closed until the work is completed”, it was revealed. “MLM will install fencing, signage and temporary access inside the station, and will deploy additional staff to provide assistance and guidance to passengers,” it was explained. “Additionally, measures will be implemented to control the flow of people, depending on the influx”, it was indicated. The Government and MLM recommend “passengers to pay attention to the information available at the station” and “plan their journeys in advance”. “MLM would like to thank citizens for their understanding of the inconvenience caused during the construction of the work”, it was added.

item.title: Consumption | New local Carnival starts today
item.description: Another Carnival of Consumption begins today, this time only centered on the northern part of the peninsula. The initiative that runs until February 20th has different formats. Every purchase over MOP100 entitles you to a weekly draw of discount coupons of up to MOP50. The only accepted electronic payment method is the Bank of China application Another Carnival of Consumption begins today, in an edition dedicated to the northern part of the peninsula and in a different format from the last editions. Over the course of six weeks, until February 20th, anyone who makes purchases worth more than 100 patacas in more than 470 stores participating in the program will be eligible for a weekly draw for three discount coupons with values ​​of 10, 20, 30 and 50 patacas. This time, the only accepted electronic payment platform is the application of the Bank of China, one of the partners in organizing the initiative, along with the Industrial and Commercial Association of the North Zone of Macau. Another difference compared to previous editions is the extension of the period in which coupons can be used, which is now daily, instead of just on weekends. Discounts can be used within a period of 14 days after the draw, for purchases worth double the amount of the coupon, that is, a MOP 10 coupon can be used for a purchase of 20 patacas. When presenting the measure, the president of the Industrial and Commercial Association of the North Zone of Macau, Wong Kin Chong, estimated that participating traders could see an increase in business volume of between 20 and 30 percent. "This is our expectation, as the event will take place before the Lunar New Year. For now, we will award electronic coupons worth one million patacas. This will generate at least two million patacas in transactions, but we hope that the amount can reach 10 million patacas", added the person in charge, according to TDM's Canal Macau. Lucky shots The initiative is still open to the registration of more commercial establishments in the northern part of the peninsula. The organization stressed that once again the measure was designed to stimulate consumption in restaurants and retail in around half of the stores and restaurants in the area. In addition to discount coupons, Wong Kin Chong indicated that some stores and restaurants will run their own promotions to encourage customers. As has been common in previous editions, consumers who participate in the initiative automatically qualify for a draw that takes place at the end of the campaign, which will distribute a car, a motorcycle, cell phones, household appliances, among other prizes.

item.title: Book | Changes in Portuguese colonial policy at the end of the 19th century
item.description: Defended in 2018, the doctoral thesis by Célia Reis, professor and researcher in contemporary History, has just been published in a book by the Macau Scientific and Cultural Center with the support of the Macau Foundation. “The Power between Lisbon and the East – Persistences and Changes in Administration. From the Ultimatum to the Colonial Act” circulates between Macau, India and Timor and brings “a good contribution to the history of colonial power” Célia Reis, professor and researcher in the area of ​​Contemporary History at Universidade Nova de Lisboa, has just published her doctoral thesis in a book focused on Portuguese colonial power in the East from the end of the 19th century. “Power between Lisbon and the East – Persistences and Changes in Administration. From the Ultimatum to the Colonial Act” is an edition of the Macau Scientific and Cultural Center (CCCM), supported by the Macau Foundation (FM), and arises from the thesis defended in 2018. To HM, Célia Reis argued that this book and its research bring “a good contribution to the history of colonial power”, focusing “on the administrative configurations in the colonies of the East, India, Macau and Timor, in the period between the Ultimatum and the Colonial Act”, published in 1930. “Thousands of documents” were analyzed, namely “formal letters, private letters, reports from departments, drafts, small notes” that demonstrate decisions and the functioning of the Administration in the territories of Portuguese India, Macau and Timor. We speak, according to the author, of “a time of many experiments, in different phases”, and, for Célia Reis, “a gap that existed in Portuguese historiography” was overcome in the sense of a better understanding of the functioning of Portuguese colonial power in these years, and specifically in the territories to the East. In the case of Macau, the book and study contribute “to an administrative history of the period in question”, namely “why it was decided, how it was decided; what problems were posed at an administrative level; how the power of Lisbon was felt and how it was resolved, or how it sought to influence the central power; or who represented it”. The territory is also placed “alongside two other spaces, India and Timor, which are very different, enabling a comparative history, an emphasis on what was common or specific, which, without a doubt, is essential for deeper knowledge”. Célia Reis says she is “very happy with the publication”, for being able to “share the work, investigations and their results, with the public, helping to better understand the history and lived realities”. Historical adjustments The years dedicated to this research show many changes in colonial policy, taking into account that “the colonization movement seen from the last decades of the 19th century was reflected in the way of governing the colonies, giving rise to discussions, studies and adaptations to realities”. Célia Reis further explained that “the existing framework, which had been institutionalized since 1869, was being altered by the creation of new departments, the introduction of new forms of financial control or the change in the status and organization of some colonies, making the administration less homogeneous than was seen in many speeches”. At issue is, in particular, a decree dated December 1, 1869, which proved to be the “true organic charter of the Overseas Provinces”, as stated in the conclusion of the work, without forgetting the Administrative Code of 1842, which “shaped the overseas political bodies for decades”. “Although they lead to a continuous model, in the bodies and their functions, they did not prevent the progressive organization of new configurations or the adaptation of different structures”, we also read. The researcher highlights the occurrence of successive attempts at modernization in legislative and administrative terms, even before the implementation of the First Republic. “Several proposals for modifications were made, with a more modernizing intention, and which had greater emphasis from the last years of the Monarchy, continuing later through the Republic for a more structured change, which ended up being carried out by laws published in 1914 and 1920”. From October 5, 1910, when the Monarchy fell and a republican regime was established, there was “a ministerial change, with the assumption of reference to colonies replacing Ultramar and the autonomy of its ministry”. "In overseas areas, the change of regime was understood as an opportunity for administrative renewal, as can be understood by India's proposal, or by the openness expressed by government bodies to changes in Macau. But the new republican regime remained, in the field of colonial administration, trapped in the circumstances of its beginning, by constitutionalizing it. In fact, in the wide range of changes, colonial issues constituted only one part and parliamentarians did not dedicate themselves sufficiently to them, despite the existence of proposals”, reads the conclusion of the work. In the years of Republicanism, there was “political processing that imposed a framework of parliamentarism, due to some distrust towards the Executive”, and at the level of the colonies “this option led to greater interference by the Senate in the appointment of governors, moving away from what were considered more effective models”. Furthermore, “the rupture also did not take place in the field of participation in Congress, where overseas territories maintained their space in the political game”. "The republican decision also showed a conservative nature in relation to municipal bodies. As it was not possible to carry out a more in-depth study here, it was found that the political vision based on the importance of the municipality, as a space for participation, prevented the deeper changes that were proposed for the internal organization", is mentioned in the conclusion. Barriers and control “Obstacles occurred, such as Sidonism”, followed, with attempts at change being found to be “insufficient”. It should be noted that Sidonism had its origins in a military coup carried out by Sidónio Pais against the republican regime in force in those years, since 1910, and which operated between 1917 and 1918. It was an authoritarian and militaristic regime. According to Célia Reis, it was after the Military Dictatorship of 1926 that “we moved towards greater control” in terms of colonial policy. In general terms, “the regime that began on October 5th was, in short, modernizing in some sense, but its political conceptions and the insertion of colonial issues in the broader space of changes to be carried out in the country allowed the persistence of many previous modes”. “Despite these limitations, the 1914 laws undoubtedly constituted a modernizing step, replacing the existing framework”, concluded Célia Reis, referring to the years of Sidonism as “a rupture in the path that was being followed, with the retreat of colonial capabilities, particularly collegiate bodies and local participation, as well as a decrease in financial autonomy”. This “political trend” experienced in the then metropolis ended up “transplanted overseas”. In terms of documentation used in this investigation, we have the example of the Organic Charters, implemented by Portugal for each colony, and which “arose following the laws of 1914”, analyzing “the various proposals existing in India, Macau and Timor, their implementation process, the essential characteristics of those that belonged to those colonies and their subsequent trajectory”. According to the investigation, “they were the product of the moment in which they took place, inserted in a broader change introduced in Portugal by the Republic, which conditioned their existence, firstly due to the different contributions they had and, later, due to the lack of definition of their situation”. This study analyzes “the way in which central and colonial decisions were operationalized”, having considered “governmental and parliamentary structures”. In the case of colonies, “their organs of power” were studied, where “the governor, interlocutor between metropolis and colony, acted, examining his capabilities and possibility of action, when he was under the authority of a distant ministry, but alongside other supervisory powers, particularly financial, Councils and, in general, under pressure from the various forces of the colony”. In the case of the “competences and composition of the various Councils and means of financial control” they have experienced, in these years, “a change, much more pronounced throughout the various reforms; mainly integrating civil servants”. Furthermore, “the combination of other elements of local society proved to be different, depending on the colonies”. Orders of Lisbon Célia Reis describes that “local deliberations were dependent on superior sanction and remained so beyond the reforms”, and “the practice often circumvented the norm, maintaining uncertainty as a form of action”. Another point to highlight in this study is how the fact that Lisbon made the most important decisions affected life in the colonies. "Although the mandatory sanction remained, the legislation introduced changes, mainly based on the establishment of deadlines. Nevertheless, the metropolitan decision-making capacity remained essential, affecting the life of the colonies. The forms used, persisting what existed or changing the framework, essentially constituted adaptations to the circumstances that occurred, responding both to foreign models and to the needs imposed on Portuguese realities. Politics, in its instability and phases of change, also determined this path", he said.

The sixth and final UNESCO criterion for this classification involves the caves being “strongly associated with the history of transcontinental relations and the spread of Buddhism throughout Asia”. “For centuries, the Dunhuang oasis, close to the bifurcation of the two branches of the Silk Road, benefited from the status of a transit station where not only goods were exchanged, but also ideas, as demonstrated by the Chinese, Tibetan, Sogdian, Khotan, Uyghur and even Hebrew manuscripts found in the caves”, it is described.

item.title: Macau Tower | Show celebrates Sino-Portuguese culture
item.description: A new theatrical show takes the stage tomorrow to explore how 500 years of contact between Portuguese and Chinese cultures gave Macau “a unique identity”. In the third edition of the “Macasaphis” series, the experimental theater group Frost Ice Snow Creative brings together music, theater, fashion, oral stories and stand-up comedy in the Macau Tower auditorium. The director, Sileas Ko Weng Si, told Lusa yesterday that, after a two-year break due to lack of funding, the group decided to return with the theme “Sino-Portuguese culture”. "Sino-Portuguese culture is everywhere, but we don't even realize it anymore. People often get confused, without understanding how it influences our lives", explained Sileas Ko. The first edition of “Macasahpis”, in 2022, had already been dedicated to particular elements of the region. “The presence of the Chinese and Portuguese languages, the historical monuments, the fact that we have the largest number of holidays in the world, both Buddhist and Catholic,” said Ko. Portuguese is one of the two official languages ​​of Macau, at least during the first 50 years of the new semi-autonomous Chinese region, according to the bilateral agreement that allowed the transition of administration in December 1999. The 2023 edition had as guests Tuna Macaense, a musical group from the Eurasian community, made up mainly of Portuguese descendants, who play songs in the Creole dialect, Patuá. But this time the group decided to go further and celebrate how Portuguese influence is also felt among the Chinese in Macau, the show's producer, Casta Lai Chit, told Lusa. “Maybe people still feel some shame in defining our culture and identity, because we are Chinese, but we are not the same as others”, explained Casta Lai, who has Portuguese nationality. “People are proud of Macau’s culture, but they have some shame in showing it”, lamented Sileas Ko. "Sino-Portuguese culture makes our city even more special. Without it, there would only be casinos", he added. Cultural power With an area of ​​just 33 square kilometers and less than 680,000 inhabitants, Macau “is a tiny fish” in the context of China, with a population of 1.4 billion, Casta Lai highlighted. “If it weren’t for Sino-Portuguese culture, Macau wouldn’t be important at all,” argued the producer. The show includes a part in which, in a humorous way, the population of Macau is treated as “an endangered species” and not just because the city has the lowest birth rate in the world, said Sileas Ko. Casta Lai warned that "maybe after 50 years the culture will be different. If that happens, maybe people will look around and miss what was lost."

item.title: Iran threatens to retaliate against US and Israel in case of attack
item.description: The president of Iran's parliament warned yesterday that the US military and Israel will be “legitimate targets” in the event of an attack by Washington, as threatened by US President Donald Trump. Mohammad Bagher Qalibaf's comments represent the first time that Israel has been included on the list of possible targets for an Iranian attack. Qalibaf, an Iranian hard-liner who has run for president in the past, made the threat as deputies stormed the parliament rostrum, shouting: “Death to America!” During the parliament session, broadcast live on Iranian state television, Mohammad Qalibaf gave a speech applauding the police and Iran's paramilitary Revolutionary Guard, particularly its Basij volunteers, for having “remained firm” during the protests held in the country against the Iranian theocracy. “The people of Iran must know that we will deal with them in the most severe manner and punish those who are detained,” he said. Qalibaf went on to directly threaten Israel, referring to it as “the occupied territory”, and also the US military: “In the event of an attack on Iran, both the occupied territory and all American military centers, bases and ships in the region will be our legitimate targets”, he stated, adding: “We do not consider ourselves limited to react after action and will act based on any objective signs of threat”. The seriousness of Iran's intentions regarding launching a potential attack is still unclear, especially after the country's air defenses were destroyed during June's 12-day war with Israel. Any decision to go to war would be up to Iran's supreme leader, 86-year-old 'Ayatollah' Ali Khamenei. Death on the street The US military has stated in the Middle East that it is “positioned with forces that span the full range of combat capabilities to defend itself, partners and allies, and US interests.” Meanwhile, the protests that have been taking place in Iran for two weeks, challenging the regime and which, according to the Human Rights Activists News Agency (HDRANA), have already caused at least 192 deaths, led protesters yesterday to flood the streets of the capital and the country's second largest city. The New York Times and Wall Street Journal, citing unnamed US officials, said Saturday night that Trump had been given military options for an attack on Iran but had not made a final decision.

item.title: Tourism | Prices rose 1.7 percent last year
item.description: In 2025, the average Tourist Price Index (IPT) rose 1.71 percent, compared to 2024, mainly due to the increase in prices for jewelry and entertainment and leisure. Data released by the Statistics and Census Services show a reduction in the price of hotel rooms. Last year, analysis of “miscellaneous goods”, such as jewelry, watches and handicrafts, shows a price increase of 13.46 percent. In relation to “fun and cultural activities” the annual increase was 8.2 percent. However, the accommodation price index showed a reduction of 2.88 percent, as did the price index for medicines and personal goods with a decrease of 1.93 percent. In the fourth quarter of 2025, the IPT grew 4.95 percent, in annual terms, driven by the rise in prices for jewelry (17.33 percent), hotel rooms (7.33 percent) and airline tickets (6.05 percent).

item.title: Ana Cristina Alves
item.description: Ana Cristina Alves – Assistant Researcher and Coordinator of the Educational Service of the Macau Scientific and Cultural Center Simone Weil was born in Paris on February 3, 1909 and died on August 24, 1943, she lived little and intensely in a troubled time, crossed by two major world wars, the first between 1914 and 1918, and the second, between 1939 and 1945, particularly marked in her life. She was an outstanding French philosopher, of Jewish origin, teacher, politician and activist. Then he turned to mystical thought, leaving us with profound reflections on his relationship with God. He died at the age of 34 of heart failure while almost fasting, restricting his diet to a minimum, it is said, in a possible reading, by an occupied France in a gesture of solidarity with his compatriots who lived poorly and under the tutelage of the Nazis, while he was working for the French government in exile in Great Britain. He learned ancient Greek to speak in code with his older brother, mathematician André Weil, so that his parents could not understand them. Later he began studying Sanskrit, in order to be able to read Bhagavad Gita in the original and, at the time of his revolutionary furor, he was also a pacifist and trade unionist, concentrating his activity on literature classes for the working classes, as he considered that French literature was the right way to educate the workers' spirit and revolution in accordance with their cultural tradition. Later she visited anarchic thought, maintaining her pacifist vocation until she was confronted with the Nazi regime and the occupation of France. He reacted by joining the French Resistance, but he felt a strong spiritual call, so along with political activism, he developed a deep mysticism, despite having grown up in an agnostic environment. The call to the Christian faith began in 1935, in Portugal, having been touched by the beauty of our churches, while on vacation in Póvoa do Varzim. Later, in 1937, he felt religious ecstasy in Assisi in the small Romanesque chapel of Santa Maria degli Angeli, where Saint Francis used to pray. However, it is necessary to keep in mind that she was interested in several religious traditions that included the Greek and Egyptian mysteries, Hinduism, Mahayana Buddhism, among the religious experiences that culminated in her relationship not with Catholicism, but with Christianity, without ever advocating any type of religious syncretism. Let's move on to the presentation of the second thinker in this article, Byung-Chul Han, one of the best-known South Korean thinkers in the West, born in Seoul in 1959. He studied Metallurgy, later living in Germany, where he studied Philosophy at the University of Freiburg and German Literature and Theology at the University of Munich, currently teaching Philosophy at the University of Arts in Berlin. The philosopher brings us Conversations about God – A Dialogue with Simone Weil, in a 2025 publication, very well translated by Ana Falcão Bastos in Relógio D´Água Editores. His conversation with the philosopher Simone Weil develops around a reflection on God, combining his readings and interpretation of her thoughts, with him strongly heir to the Eastern immanentist tradition, which is why in the last chapter, entitled Inactivity, he fervently states: "Simone Weil imagines a kind of panpsychism. Everything is alive and animated. Without the spirituality of the universe, no relationship between it and the human spirit is possible" (Han, 2025, 81). According to his perspective, which he always believes he shares with Simone Weil, in order to talk to God an appropriate ethical stance is necessary, analyzed in the seven chapters into which he divides the work. It is then necessary to cultivate and accept Attention, Uncreation, Emptiness, Silence, Beauty, Pain and Inactivity. These are the right inner and outer ingredients to maintain a close relationship with God, who is not dead, as Nietzsche proclaimed, but rather very present to a humanity that does not seem to be capable of listening to or contemplating him. “It is not God who is dead, but the man to whom God revealed himself” (Han, 2025, 11), so we must cultivate the attention of the spirit, turn it towards God and this is done first and foremost with the teachings of Simone Weil: she died from the heart, in an exhausted, tubercular and bloodless body, or out of solidarity, or out of the belief that the less she ate, the more and better she would achieve union with God. Note the following reflection: "Two birds, inseparable companions, perch on the same tree. One eats the fruit from the tree, the other watches without eating." (Weil apud Han, 2025, 11). The world, according to both thinkers, is full of information, programs, and wrong attitudes, for example, binge watching, which means “devouring television programs”, in addition to all types of distractions, entertainment and food. Thus, it is advocated in the Buddhist or Taoist way, that it is necessary to be frugal, in a literal and metaphorical sense, to fast so that the soul triggers a process of “autophagy” leading to God, because “Only this autophagy of the soul saves and leads to God.” (Han, 2025, 12). In this way, the organism will eat its own meat, transforming it into energy. This practical philosophy taken to its ultimate consequences implies death, as happened to Simone Weil, when already very weakened, she saw her heart giving of itself. There is, however, a middle ground, which will need to be taken into account to develop the spirit's attention, as the spirit immersed in the flesh becomes incapable of concentrating. If absolute fasting is dangerous, as the Historical Buddha discovered sitting under the Ficus Religiosa, relative fasting, or rather dietary simplicity, can stimulate “contemplative attention” essential to seeing God. This vision requires deep attention, which can be used to solve a scientific or artistic problem, as in the God vision, because “God is attention without distraction” (Han, 2025, 14). Attention will thus be exercised in total concentration, similar to that used in prayer, in connection with the sacred, which is at the same time the supreme good, recalling the two forces of love and hate of the pre-Socratic philosopher Empedocles. These operate in the cosmos, making it organized, connected, attentive and loving, or disconnected, distracted and hateful. "Good unites and reconciles, while evil separates and divides. Evil is multifaceted. Good, on the contrary, is based on a single truth." (Han, 2025, 17). It is therefore natural to promote, within the framework of both thinkers, an “ethics of attention” or an ethics of mercy/compassion (Han, 2025,74), as only through this can a connection be achieved with others and, above all, with the Other, in an empathetic, spontaneous and deep connection. The way Byung-Chul Han defines Christian virtue is very interesting: “Christian virtue is not a search, it is not an action, but rather a waiting and observing (…) the role of the future wife is to wait” (Han, 2025, 18). I believe that, although it is an authorized reading of this virtue, the emphasis given to contemplative attention and waiting finds its reason for being within many Asian philosophies, which privilege non-action and even inactivity, as occurs in the seventh chapter of the work, being described in terms of the correct way of contact with the sacred, in an obedient, humble and silent posture. The author tells us, excluding the will, as much as possible: “It is inactivity that gives wings to the soul” (Han, 2025, 19) Perhaps for this reason, the first etymological definition of religion offered in the text refers to attention and the term religo means “relegere (reread)” (Han, 2025, 20). First of all, you need to know how to read the signs and pray or, in a more Eastern nomenclature, meditate. And continuing along this line that crosses East and West, to properly cultivate attention it is necessary to “empty” the soul to prepare it for connection to the sacred, which will allow us to introduce, in the last chapter, the second most common etymological definition in the West, “Religion as religare, means to connect, bind or unite” (Han, 2025,84) in a “reconnecting” what has been disconnected, the sacred and the profane in the style of Taoist and Buddhist philosophies. In this logic of thought of the South Korean philosopher, who talks to the French philosopher, emptiness is fundamental, not to give encouragement to life, as stated in the fourth chapter of the Book of Way and Virtue (《道德经》), and remember: “the Tao is an empty vessel/it is used and never becomes full./unfathomable source of ten thousand things” (道冲而用之或不盈/渊兮似万物之宗)(Abreu, 2013,34-5), but, more in a Buddhist or Platonic way, to favor death. Cultivating emptiness is learning to be nothing, to uncreate oneself or lose the self, to renounce: “Empty means, ultimately, learning to die, surrendering oneself to death: «Praying is like death»” (Han, 2025,51). This reading, which is very indebted to Eastern tradition, is contrasted with an active Western Christian virtue, which finds God not in contemplative attention, although one can also be present there, but in active life, in relationships with others in the exercise of compassion or permanent love so that the kingdom of God descends as much as possible to earth. The definition of love advanced by Han, through Weil, is that of a “gaze of the soul”, that is, “love is based on the look as the attention of the soul.” (Han, 2025, 22). The cultivation of contemplation, waiting, silence and emptiness can lead to the presence of God, being a possible reading of the Sermon on the Mount, in which Jesus teaches that the lilies of the field and the birds of Heaven do not need to work or spin, God offers life as a gift and divine grace. However, if being is nothing, if obedience, silence and renunciation can lead to a theodynamics of love, care and attention must be taken that this is directed and concentrated on the relationship with God, because in human society an overwhelming thermodynamic of power dominates and according to the Western tradition we cannot run the risk of falling into the trap of power, because, as the author clearly sees, although he does not draw the ultimate consequences of what he writes: “Whoever has power has the feeling that they are growing spatially. It expands or extends. The increase in power manifests itself with an increase in the self” (Han, 2025, 42). The “re-connected” being will have to distinguish very carefully between the sacred and the profane, ensuring that their connection is true, or otherwise they will become a silent and renouncing nothing before their fellow man, which is absolutely intolerable for all the children of the same Father, as well as for the heirs of the Western philosophical tradition. Obviously, it is not advocating a thermodynamic power relationship, that is, full of energy and always expanding, that the author has in mind. Therefore, from a concrete and human point of view, it advises work relationships outside the master/slave connection, so denounced by Nietzsche in his attack on the Christian religion. In the mundane sphere, Han proposes that we escape either the labor relations created by industrial capitalist societies, in which “human beings are trained to become mechanical labor cattle” (Han, 2025,78), or by neoliberal performance societies in which people believe they are authentic and creative, but in reality embark on a productive frenzy in which they become “slaves of themselves” (Ibidem). So what seems to be the best solution for human beings in a world where work is fundamental? I confess that the author's response surprised and captivated me. The solution is to make work a loving theodynamic process, that is, not to carry it out without meaning, but to dedicate your actions to God, which for a Christian means, working out of love for others, carrying out a symbolic act, in the etymological sense of the term, as union and yet another way of penetrating the sacred sphere. Therefore, labor is poeticized, making it creative, in the manner of Simone Weil or Byung-Chul Han: "It is, therefore, about giving work a contemplative and spiritual character. Elevating it "to the highest point, that of the fullness of attention, which is the fullness of prayer." (Han, 2025, 85) Bibliographic References Abreu, António Graça de (trans.). 2013. Laozi. item.title: Today Macau
item.description: The Chinese Government reaffirmed Friday that, regardless of what happens in Venezuela, the Asian country will continue to support Caracas in defending its sovereignty and national security. “China will continue to firmly support Venezuela in safeguarding its sovereignty, dignity and national security, regardless of how the political situation evolves,” said Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Mao Ning. The spokesperson highlighted that Beijing has maintained “solid” communication and cooperation with the Venezuelan Government and that the country “is deeply committed to deepening practical cooperation and promoting common development”. The Asian country, which has maintained close relations with Caracas in recent years, harshly condemned the United States' military intervention in Venezuela and demanded the release of former president Nicolás Maduro and his wife, Cilia Flores, who were taken to New York. The interim president of Venezuela, Delcy Rodríguez, met on Thursday with the Chinese ambassador, Lan Hu, highlighting China's “firm and consistent position in strongly condemning the serious violation of international law and Venezuelan sovereignty”, according to official Venezuelan information. North American sources cited by the ABC television network indicated that the Administration of the President of the United States, Donald Trump, informed Rodríguez that Venezuela will have to end its relations with China, Russia, Iran and Cuba as a condition for being able to extract and sell its oil.

item.title: Paulo Maia and Carmo
item.description: Mo Shilong (1537-87), referring to one of the most cherished masters in the canon of painting history, known by the name Ni Yunlin zi, the «Master of the cloud forest», the painter Nizan (1306-1374), who was revealed when, in the turmoil of the violent dynastic transition, he said «no» to those closest to him, starting to live as a recluse, noted that «when ordinary people try imitate an original painting, how can they transmit its spirit to posterity?” Later, the influential theorist Dong Qichang (1555-1636) added: «Those who study the old masters and do not introduce changes are like trapped behind a fence. By imitating models too closely you are often even further away». And Nizan's paintings, perhaps even more than many others, in their serene austere aspect will be the most difficult to imitate because they depend intimately on the person of their author and the way in which he managed to make the «spiritual rhythm» (qiyun) flow in them. And yet many tried to reproduce the elegant and insipid (dan) appearance of those visions that were closer to their spirit than to the external visible. Later, in another dynastic transition, from the Ming to the Qing dynasty, a painter tried to follow Nizan's path from within, in similar circumstances. He belonged to a family of seven brothers, from Shanyin (now part of Shaoxing, Zhejiang). One of the brothers, the illustrated imperial official Qi Biaojia (1603-45), would leave a unique record of the sophistication of the literati at the end of the Ming dynasty, significantly through the memory of his Yu garden, on the slope of the hill of the same name. In the «Yu Hill Anthology», Yushan zhi, a collective work in three volumes written by him, his friends and family, travel notes, explanations of views of the garden, narratives, inquiries, dreams of personalities who interpreted their present with knowledge of the rich arts and literature of the past are kept, constituting a relevant historical archive. Which was found expressively in paintings. Qi Zhijia (1594-c.1682), another of the brothers, in addition to being a poet, playwright, calligrapher, stamp engraver, athlete and amateur singer, had a memory of paintings, as shown in several works made in the style of great masters. If, faced with the disruption of the new foreign government, Qi Biaojia would commit suicide in his garden, as four thousand and forty-three senior officials did, according to a record from Qianlong's time, Qi Zhijia would resist through calm contemplation, accepting impermanence, as in the 1651 vertical scroll, Landscape from Nizan (ink on paper, 116 x 50.8 cm, at the Metmuseum). In him the “dragon veins”, longmo, reveal the depth of his experience of solitude and serenity, the understanding of the spirit of Winter.

item.title: University of Macau | Former teachers recall experiences
item.description: The University of Macau celebrates 45 years and HM invited two former professors to recall their professional experiences at the institution. Brian Hall, from the field of psychology, found “the ideal environment” to start his career. Vera Lúcia Raposo says she “learned a lot” and saw Law as a “meeting place” A series of events begins this Sunday to celebrate the 45 years of existence of the University of Macau (UM), including the “Open Day” which takes place at the Lakeside Theater between 11am and 5pm (see secondary text). It was in March 1981, still under the name of the University of East Asia, that UM began to take its first steps in local higher education, namely in the teaching of Law in the Portuguese language. It was the first time that Macau had its own university, providing a higher education offering for residents, who no longer only had the opportunity to pursue studies abroad, such as Portugal, the United Kingdom, Hong Kong or Australia. To commemorate the anniversary, HM invited two former professors of the institution, from two different academic areas, to talk about their experience at UM. Vera Lúcia Raposo, who taught at the Faculty of Law from January 2014, remembers feeling “a shock”. "The classes were entirely in English, and I had never taught a complete course in that language, the pressure to publish in indexed journals was absolute and the evaluation system was periodic, demanding and relentless. Nothing there resembled the regime I was used to, where the simple passage of time often seemed to guarantee the natural advancement of an academic career", she said. However, adaptation arrived and ended up following “the rules” to this day, namely at NOVA School of Law. “At the time, however, these requirements were still profoundly strange in Portugal, and they continue to be so, in many contexts, even today”, he says. Vera Lúcia Raposo says she “learned a lot” at UM, as “the demanding scientific production goals and interdisciplinary research contributed to defining the type of academic I am today”. “I owe UM more than a professional transition, but a transformation”, he assures. A cultural melting pot The former professor at the UM Faculty of Law also remembers arriving in a territory that was “a space of true cultural amalgamation”, with the institution being an example of this. "Working side by side with colleagues of different nationalities and cultures was a rare privilege. In particular, the intellectual coexistence between Chinese, Macanese and Portuguese colleagues, in the study and teaching of Macau Law, offered me an absolutely unique way of thinking about Law: less self-centered, more dialoguing, more aware of its cultural and historical contingency", highlighted Vera Lúcia Raposo. Brian Hall, who taught at the Faculty of Social Sciences and coordinated the “Global and Community Mental Health Research Group”, highlights the possibility of doing pioneering work in the area of ​​mental health. "UM gave me the opportunity to develop unique and never-before-taught courses in Global Mental Health and Global Health. They were the first courses of their kind in Macau and at the university", recalled Brian Hall, who is now linked to New York University Shanghai. “I was grateful to have some really great students who were interested in topics like migration, global and digital mental health, and I really enjoyed mentoring them in and out of the classroom.” The first prizes The academic also highlights the fact that he “regularly published research articles with undergraduate and postgraduate students, taking them to international research conferences, where they won awards”. “We were among the first at the university to achieve these excellent results and I am eternally grateful to UM for providing me with all these opportunities”, he confessed. Brian Hall also added that he joined UM “in a period of ambitious transition and growth to become a research university”, providing “an ideal environment to launch a career”. When he was at UM, Brian Hall received, in 2020, an award for his work, the “Excellence in Advising Award” from the Center for Global Health at Johns Hopkins University, from the Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health. "The university rewarded me for my excellent research performance by granting me permission to apply for an early promotion to associate professor, which I was granted just four years after joining the university. UM served as a springboard to build a regional and international career," he said. Book of Genesis The need to create a university in Macau arose from the desire to develop the territory, especially taking into account the signing of the Joint Declaration between Portugal and China in 1987. The former Governor of Macau Garcia Leandro recalled the first moments of the creation of the future university in the book “Macau in the Years of the Portuguese Revolution 1974-1979”, which reads that the initial budget was 40 million patacas for construction “on land on the island of Taipa, with a modern architectural project”. The institution should have capacity for “a population of two thousand students in four years, at a rate of 500 per year”, with “the leadership of the various course chairs guaranteed by a dean professor with a doctorate from the University of Oxford and by several university professors from Matteo Ricci, the Chinese University of Hong Kong and also from the USA”, it is described. The first contract to train the teaching team and pedagogical content was signed in February 1979 with the Matteo Ricci group. “I believe it was another good service provided to the population”, wrote the former Governor. In 1991, the institution changed its name to what it currently has. According to data from the 2024 annual report, the latest available, UM has 52,146 graduated students, and in the first semester of the 2024/2025 academic year, 15,147 students attended the university, from all educational levels. Highlight is the greater number of students from abroad, 9,328, compared to 5,819 local students. Open day in Hengqin Despite having been formally created in March, UM begins to celebrate 45 years of existence this Sunday with an Open Day. According to a statement from the educational institution, between 11 am and 5 pm the public will be able to visit the Lakeside Theater, where the first ceremony takes place, and then other areas of the campus in Hengqin, namely the main campus and the UM Scientific and Technological Research Institute in Zhuhai, in the Youth Entrepreneurship Valley in Hengqin. This route also includes the possibility of visiting, for the first time, the Transitional Research and Education Site at Yuxin Tower, in the Cooperation Zone. “Through a wide range of on-site activities and live online broadcasts, the event will showcase UM’s latest developments and achievements in teaching, research and community service”, highlights the same note, which recalls how UM was the first higher education institution in Macau to “extend teaching and research activities to the Guangdong-Macao Deep Cooperation Zone in Hengqin”. That day there will also be “approximately 250 activities on the main campus throughout the day, including admissions lectures, academic and research activities and interactive games”. "Visitors interested in academic subjects can attend engaging lectures on science and other disciplines, while sports enthusiasts can explore UM's sports facilities. Families can also participate in interactive games at stands, scientific experiments, workshops and knowledge challenges organized by various faculties, residences and laboratories", it is revealed. On Open Day there will also be discounts in the restaurant area.

item.title: Church | Pope closes 2025 with criticism of consumerism and xenophobia
item.description: Pope Leo The speech served to close the Jubilee - a Holy Year that usually takes place every 25 years, proclaimed by the Pope as a special time of forgiveness, reconciliation and spiritual renewal -, which brought around 33 million pilgrims to Rome and included a historic transition from one American pontiff to another. In the presence of cardinals and diplomats from all over the world, Leo This situation had only occurred once, in 1700. Yesterday's ceremony, at the beginning of the mass celebrating the feast of the Epiphany (when the three Magi offered gifts to the newborn Jesus) ended a dizzying year of special audiences, masses and meetings that dominated Leo XIV's first months as pontiff and put his own agenda on hold. To signal that his pontificate can now begin in earnest, the Pope summoned cardinals from around the world to the Vatican, for meetings on Wednesday and Thursday that aim to debate the governance of the Catholic Church, with its 1.4 billion faithful. To reflect In yesterday's homily, Leo XIV said that the jubilee year invited all Christians to reflect on the biblical teachings of welcoming strangers and resisting the “flattery and seduction of those who hold power”. “Around us, a distorted economy tries to profit from everything”, he criticized, adding that he hopes that this year it will be possible to recognize “a pilgrim in the visitor, a seeker abroad, a neighbor in the stranger and a traveling companion in someone who is different”. The Holy Years usually include large public works projects, as was the case with the construction of the Sistine Chapel (commissioned by Pope Sixtus IV for the Jubilee of 1475) and the large Vatican garage, where popemobiles and other vehicles are parked (commissioned by John Paul II for the Jubilee of 2000). Some works were controversial, such as the construction of Via della Conciliazione, in 1950, which leads to St. Peter's Square and which involved the demolition of an entire neighborhood. Leo XIV also announced that the next Jubilee will be in 2033, to commemorate the 2000th anniversary of what the Scriptures indicate as the death and resurrection of Jesus Christ, in 33 AD.

item.title: Medals | Ho Iat Seng, Kou Hoi In and Raimundo do Rosário distinguished
item.description: The list of winners is marked by the award of two Medals of Honor of the Great Lotus, the highest distinction in the Macao SAR, to Ho Iat Seng and Kou Hoi In. All the individuals awarded served in the Government or in the Legislative Assembly The former Chief Executive, Ho Iat Seng, and the former president of the Legislative Assembly, Kou Hoi In, will be awarded the Great Lotus Medal of Honor, the Macao SAR's highest distinction. The list of the Executive's distinctions for 2025 was announced on December 31st, through a statement from the Social Communication Office, and the award ceremony is scheduled for January 30th, at the Macau Cultural Center. The main distinctions awarded by Sam Hou Fai were to former rulers, with Macanese and former Secretary for Transport and Public Works Raimundo do Rosário being awarded the Golden Lotus Medal of Honor. This distinction will also be awarded to Ho Veng On, former Commissioner of Audit, and Vong Man Chong, former director-general of the Customs Service. Medals of honor aim to distinguish individuals or entities that have contributed to the image and good name of the Macao SAR. After the list of medals was announced, Ho Iat Seng considered the title “a profound honor”. The former Government leader also stated, in a statement, that he “has always maintained a deep affection for Macau” and that over the years he has “dedicated” himself to “serving the nation and Macau”. The former Chief Executive praised the results of his governance and considered that they depended “not only on the dedication and hard work of the government action team and all Public Administration employees, but also on the strong support and joint efforts of the community and all residents”. “This honor is a collective victory, which demonstrates the commitment of the entire society to drive greater and better development for the Macao SAR,” he stated. The text awarding the Great Lotus Medal of Honor to Ho Iat Seng highlights the period in which the former ruler had to deal with the Covid-19 pandemic. “During his term as the fifth Chief Executive, he united the Macao SAR Government and all social sectors, successfully overcame the severe challenges and difficulties of the Covid-19 pandemic and made every effort to promote post-pandemic economic recovery and social development”, it was stated. In addition to being Chief Executive, Ho Iat Seng, a businessman by profession, was president of the Legislative Assembly, member of the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress and member of the Executive Council. This is the third time that Ho Iat Seng will be honored, after in 2001 having received the Medal of Industrial and Commercial Merit and in 2009 having been distinguished with the Golden Lotus Medal of Honor. Another Lotus Another distinguished businessman and former president of the Legislative Assembly is Kou Hoi In, notable for his activity as a member of the National People's Congress, the main legislative body of the People's Republic of China, and for more than 34 years as a deputy of the Legislative Assembly. “In legislation work, supervision of government action and formulation of public policies, it has always defended the principles of carrying out functions in accordance with the law, in a rational and pragmatic manner, actively promoted the improvement of regimes and the construction of the rule of law and committed itself to safeguarding the rights and interests of residents and promoting social stability and long-term development”, it was considered. “During his term as President of the Legislative Assembly of Macau from 2019 to 2025, he focused his efforts on improving the efficiency of parliamentary functioning, promoting positive interaction between the Executive Branch and the Legislative Branch, and made important contributions to strengthening the construction of the Rule of Law, promoting social harmony and improving the population's well-being policies”, it was added. After leaving the Chamber, Kou was appointed to serve as chairman of the Board of Directors of TDM, he is also vice-president of the Board of Directors and general manager of the China Special Products and Productions Company and vice-president of the Macau Commercial Association. In the past, the previous president of AL had been awarded the Industrial and Commercial Merit Medal in 2007 and the Silver Lotus Medal of Honor in 2016. In Portuguese Raimundo do Rosário, Secretary for Transport and Public Works, between 2014 and 2024, is the only representative of the Macanese community in the 2025 distinctions, taking into account the distinguished individuals and associations. In the text about the former ruler, several positions held in public and private institutions are indicated. “He joined the Civil Service in 1979 and worked until 1990 successively as a senior technician, head of department, deputy director and director of the Land, Public Works and Transport Services”, it can be read. His CV also states that he was a member of the Portuguese delegation of the Portuguese-Chinese Land Group, deputy of the Board of Directors of CAM-Sociedade of Macau International Airport and head of the Macau Economic and Commercial Delegation, in Lisbon, also having charge of the Economic and Commercial Delegations to the European Union, in Brussels and the World Trade Organization, in Geneva. Raimundo was also a member of the Drafting Committee of the Basic Law and the Preparatory Committee for the Establishment of the Special Administrative Region of Macau, deputy and member of the Supervisory Board of Banco Comercial de Macau. In terms of medals of honor, the Macau Banks Association will be awarded the Silver Lotus, due to its “fundamental role in promoting sector collaboration and the solid development of the industry”. Medals of Merit In the chapter on the professional merit medal this year, only one distinction appears, for Chan Iok Lin, who has been a member of the Office of the President of the Court of Final Instance since 2000, having become head in 2016. “He has always demonstrated a rigorous and dedicated attitude in carrying out his duties, possessing excellent leadership and organizational skills, as well as a high level of professionalism and a spirit of dedication”, he was justified. In the industrial and commercial area, the distinctions went to the state-owned company Companhia de Logística Nam Kwong, from the Nam Kwong group, for its contributions to the diversification of the economy and to businesswoman Amber Li Jiaming, who is president of the HN Group and member of the 14th National Committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference (CPPCC), vice-president of the CPPCC Foreign Affairs Commission and member of the Council for the Economic Development of Macau. At a tourist level, the only distinction was given to the House of Dancing Water Show Team, from Melco Resorts & Entertainment. The show was suspended during the pandemic, but returned after the end of border restrictions imposed during the years of combating Covid-19. In terms of education, the Macau University of Science and Technology, Keang Peng School and Kao Yip School were distinguished. In culture, the distinctions went to the Chinese Opera Association of Maritime and Land Residents of Barra de Macau, deputy Lam Fat Iam and artist Chan Iu Pui, who draws caricatures for the newspaper Ou Mun. Finally, an Altruistic Merit Medal will be awarded to the China International Emergency Medical Team (SAR) and Sports Merit medals to the MSAR Karate Team that participated in the National Games. Athlete Zhu Yuling, who defended the colors of Interior until 2024, when she moved to Macau, will also be honored. The athlete went on to represent the Macao SAR under professional staff promotion programs and won the women's singles title in the WTT of United States Smash Table Tennis, the first athlete from Macau to achieve this feat. Currently, she is a professor at Tianjin University. item.title: Book | Changes in Portuguese colonial policy at the end of the 19th century
item.description: Defended in 2018, the doctoral thesis by Célia Reis, professor and researcher in contemporary History, has just been published in a book by the Macau Scientific and Cultural Center with the support of the Macau Foundation. “The Power between Lisbon and the East – Persistences and Changes in Administration. From the Ultimatum to the Colonial Act” circulates between Macau, India and Timor and brings “a good contribution to the history of colonial power” Célia Reis, professor and researcher in the area of ​​Contemporary History at Universidade Nova de Lisboa, has just published her doctoral thesis in a book focused on Portuguese colonial power in the East from the end of the 19th century. “Power between Lisbon and the East – Persistences and Changes in Administration. From the Ultimatum to the Colonial Act” is an edition of the Macau Scientific and Cultural Center (CCCM), supported by the Macau Foundation (FM), and arises from the thesis defended in 2018. To HM, Célia Reis argued that this book and its research bring “a good contribution to the history of colonial power”, focusing “on the administrative configurations in the colonies of the East, India, Macau and Timor, in the period between the Ultimatum and the Colonial Act”, published in 1930. “Thousands of documents” were analyzed, namely “formal letters, private letters, reports from departments, drafts, small notes” that demonstrate decisions and the functioning of the Administration in the territories of Portuguese India, Macau and Timor. We speak, according to the author, of “a time of many experiments, in different phases”, and, for Célia Reis, “a gap that existed in Portuguese historiography” was overcome in the sense of a better understanding of the functioning of Portuguese colonial power in these years, and specifically in the territories to the East. In the case of Macau, the book and study contribute “to an administrative history of the period in question”, namely “why it was decided, how it was decided; what problems were posed at an administrative level; how the power of Lisbon was felt and how it was resolved, or how it sought to influence the central power; or who represented it”. The territory is also placed “alongside two other spaces, India and Timor, which are very different, enabling a comparative history, an emphasis on what was common or specific, which, without a doubt, is essential for deeper knowledge”. Célia Reis says she is “very happy with the publication”, for being able to “share the work, investigations and their results, with the public, helping to better understand the history and lived realities”. Historical adjustments The years dedicated to this research show many changes in colonial policy, taking into account that “the colonization movement seen from the last decades of the 19th century was reflected in the way of governing the colonies, giving rise to discussions, studies and adaptations to realities”. Célia Reis further explained that “the existing framework, which had been institutionalized since 1869, was being altered by the creation of new departments, the introduction of new forms of financial control or the change in the status and organization of some colonies, making the administration less homogeneous than was seen in many speeches”. At issue is, in particular, a decree dated December 1, 1869, which proved to be the “true organic charter of the Overseas Provinces”, as stated in the conclusion of the work, without forgetting the Administrative Code of 1842, which “shaped the overseas political bodies for decades”. “Although they lead to a continuous model, in the bodies and their functions, they did not prevent the progressive organization of new configurations or the adaptation of different structures”, we also read. The researcher highlights the occurrence of successive attempts at modernization in legislative and administrative terms, even before the implementation of the First Republic. “Several proposals for modifications were made, with a more modernizing intention, and which had greater emphasis from the last years of the Monarchy, continuing later through the Republic for a more structured change, which ended up being carried out by laws published in 1914 and 1920”. From October 5, 1910, when the Monarchy fell and a republican regime was established, there was “a ministerial change, with the assumption of reference to colonies replacing Ultramar and the autonomy of its ministry”. "In overseas areas, the change of regime was understood as an opportunity for administrative renewal, as can be understood by India's proposal, or by the openness expressed by government bodies to changes in Macau. But the new republican regime remained, in the field of colonial administration, trapped in the circumstances of its beginning, by constitutionalizing it. In fact, in the wide range of changes, colonial issues constituted only one part and parliamentarians did not dedicate themselves sufficiently to them, despite the existence of proposals”, reads the conclusion of the work. In the years of Republicanism, there was “political processing that imposed a framework of parliamentarism, due to some distrust towards the Executive”, and at the level of the colonies “this option led to greater interference by the Senate in the appointment of governors, moving away from what were considered more effective models”. Furthermore, “the rupture also did not take place in the field of participation in Congress, where overseas territories maintained their space in the political game”. "The republican decision also showed a conservative nature in relation to municipal bodies. As it was not possible to carry out a more in-depth study here, it was found that the political vision based on the importance of the municipality, as a space for participation, prevented the deeper changes that were proposed for the internal organization", is mentioned in the conclusion. Barriers and control “Obstacles occurred, such as Sidonism”, followed, with attempts at change being found to be “insufficient”. It should be noted that Sidonism had its origins in a military coup carried out by Sidónio Pais against the republican regime in force in those years, since 1910, and which operated between 1917 and 1918. It was an authoritarian and militaristic regime. According to Célia Reis, it was after the Military Dictatorship of 1926 that “we moved towards greater control” in terms of colonial policy. In general terms, “the regime that began on October 5th was, in short, modernizing in some sense, but its political conceptions and the insertion of colonial issues in the broader space of changes to be carried out in the country allowed the persistence of many previous modes”. “Despite these limitations, the 1914 laws undoubtedly constituted a modernizing step, replacing the existing framework”, concluded Célia Reis, referring to the years of Sidonism as “a rupture in the path that was being followed, with the retreat of colonial capabilities, particularly collegiate bodies and local participation, as well as a decrease in financial autonomy”. This “political trend” experienced in the then metropolis ended up “transplanted overseas”. In terms of documentation used in this investigation, we have the example of the Organic Charters, implemented by Portugal for each colony, and which “arose following the laws of 1914”, analyzing “the various proposals existing in India, Macau and Timor, their implementation process, the essential characteristics of those that belonged to those colonies and their subsequent trajectory”.
