According to the investigation, “they were the product of the moment in which they took place, inserted in a broader change introduced in Portugal by the Republic, which conditioned their existence, firstly due to the different contributions they had and, later, due to the lack of definition of their situation”. This study analyzes “the way in which central and colonial decisions were operationalized”, having considered “governmental and parliamentary structures”. In the case of colonies, “their organs of power” were studied, where “the governor, interlocutor between metropolis and colony, acted, examining his capabilities and possibility of action, when he was under the authority of a distant ministry, but alongside other supervisory powers, particularly financial, Councils and, in general, under pressure from the various forces of the colony”. In the case of the “competences and composition of the various Councils and means of financial control” they have experienced, in these years, “a change, much more pronounced throughout the various reforms; mainly integrating civil servants”. Furthermore, “the combination of other elements of local society proved to be different, depending on the colonies”. Lisbon Orders Célia Reis describes that “local deliberations were dependent on superior sanction and remained so beyond the reforms”, and “the practice often circumvented the norm, maintaining uncertainty as a form of action”. Another point to highlight in this study is how the fact that Lisbon took the most important decisions affected life in the colonies. "Although the mandatory sanction remained, the legislation introduced changes, mainly based on the establishment of deadlines. Nevertheless, the metropolitan decision-making capacity remained essential, affecting the life of the colonies. The forms used, persisting what existed or changing the framework, essentially constituted adaptations to the circumstances that occurred, responding both to foreign models and to the needs imposed on Portuguese realities. Politics, in its instability and phases of change, also determined this path", he said.

item.title: Economy | Deputies warn of lack of trust and inequalities
item.description: Despite economic growth throughout this year, Chan Lai Kei and Leong Sun Iok alerted the Government to the problems in community neighborhoods and the need to distribute financial resources more equitably Deputy Chan Lai Kei called on the Government to focus on promoting economic optimism and consumption, considering that in several neighborhoods in Macau the economic situation is worrying, despite macroeconomic growth. The matter was brought to the Legislative Assembly yesterday, an intervention before the agenda in the Plenary. According to the deputy linked to the Fujian community, the economy is showing a “stable recovery”. Between January and September “the initial value of GDP grew 4.2 percent compared to the same period last year”. It also indicated that the unemployment rate was 2.3 percent between August and October. However, Chan warned that “positive macroeconomic data have not completely eliminated negative indicators”, especially with regard to the lives of the population. Citing a “recent study”, the legislator indicated that there is a weak desire to consume, because “residents’ confidence in increasing income and their satisfaction with their financial situation are still between a low and medium level”. Chan Lai Kei explained that greater consumption abroad contributes to this wave of pessimism, but also the various closures of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs): “In view of the stress of consumption abroad, the business environment of SMEs in areas linked to the lives of the population (such as NAPE, Iao Hon and Fai Chi Kei) continues to worsen and the risk of closure remains”, he warned. “These companies generally face the critical challenge of unstable customer sources, high costs and cross-border consumption”, he stressed. Given the scenario outlined, the deputy asked the Executive to create a consumption incentive mechanism similar to discount vouchers, but with a permanent nature, while the “transformation phase of Macau's economic model” lasts, which “reinforces confidence in business”. Improve distribution Deputy Leong Sun Iok also addressed the situation of the economy and pointed out the need to better distribute resources from gambling, the main industry in the territory. The legislator linked to the Federation of Workers' Associations of Macau praised the gaming concessionaires for the greater role they have taken in terms of investment for “urban development, tourism promotion and social security”, mainly since 2023. However, he regretted that resources are being channeled unequally: "It appears that, currently, both the revenues from the game and the gaming concessionaire companies themselves have invested a lot of resources in social development. But, in general, these resources are dispersed and lack a system and interconnection, therefore, they are unable to achieve maximum social benefit", he pointed out. Leong thus advocated that a greater proportion of the revenue collected by the Administration from gambling be channeled to the Social Security Fund, to pay pensions for the elderly. The deputy also called for the creation of a fund with money from concessionaires to develop the Macao SAR and to ensure that they “better” fulfill the obligations of the gaming law, such as “worker guarantees”, “support for people with disabilities or those rehabilitated”, support for SMEs and “educational, scientific research, environmental protection, cultural and sporting activities and activities of public interest”. Leong Sun Iok also requested a new portal with public information on concessionaires' expenses with non-gambling activities covered by concession obligations and ended the intervention with a request for caution addressed to the Executive. “Society’s resources do not come easily and are the result of the joint efforts of the Government, companies, the various social sectors and the population in general”, he indicated. "The situation is not always good. I hope the Government makes good use of the resources arising from the social responsibilities of gaming companies, to improve the lives of the population", he highlighted. Minimum Wage | Approved increase of one pataca per hour The increase of one pataca per hour in the minimum wage, from 34 to 35 patacas, was approved yesterday in the Legislative Assembly. With the changes, starting next year, in weekly terms, the salary will go from 1,632 patacas to 1,680 patacas. When the monthly calculations are made, the salary increases from 7,072 patacas to 7,280 patacas, an increase of 2.9 percent that will cover 4.4 percent of Macao SAR workers. Domestic workers are excluded, although the approval of the hiring quota, in the case of non-residents, is normally associated with the requirement of a salary between 3,500 and 4,000 patacas. Budget 2026 | Deputies approve the specialty The Legislative Assembly yesterday approved the budget for next year, which foresees an increase in gaming revenue of 3.5 percent, to 236 billion patacas. The document, which reflects the Executive's economic choices, estimates revenues of 118.8 billion patacas, while expenses are estimated at 113.5 billion patacas. Based on these perspectives, the final balance of the regular budget should be positive at 5.3 billion patacas. However, there is a possibility that the scenario is actually better, given that the Government tends to make default estimates with regard to revenue and expenses. The budget also once again provides for exemption from paying professional tax, up to 30 percent of the annual amount, limited to 144 thousand patacas.

item.title: UCM | White Paper suggests methods to accelerate economic diversification
item.description: The “White Paper on Scientific and Technological Cooperation between China and Portuguese-speaking Countries”, produced at the City University of Macau, refers to inequalities in the relationship between countries and concludes that “economic diversification has advanced at a slow pace”. Bárbara Morais, main writer of the document, explains the main conclusions of the analysis On December 3rd, a White Paper was launched that provides a look and analysis of the way in which cooperation in scientific and technological areas between China, Macau and Portuguese-speaking countries has been taking place, outlining some criticisms, not only on this topic, but also on the economic direction that the Macao SAR is taking. The document, entitled “White Paper on Scientific and Technological Cooperation between China and Portuguese-speaking Countries”, was produced by the City University of Macau (UCM) and had Bárbara Morais, a doctoral student at the institution, as main writer. In an interview with HM, she describes that, in Macau, “economic diversification has advanced at a slower pace than desired, keeping the economy structurally dependent on gambling and tourism”. "The central message of the White Paper is clear: Macau needs to accelerate the transition to functions with greater added value. However, the current context offers a renewed window of opportunity. With the support of the Greater Bay Area and, very specifically, the Deep Cooperation Zone in Hengqin, Macau now has new structural opportunities to recover lost momentum and reposition itself, not just as a cultural bridge, but as a true platform for innovation", he said. Still on the territory, but in relation to Forum Macau, the “success in institutionalizing political dialogue” is mentioned, but the White Paper “points the finger at the insufficiency of execution mechanisms”. “To streamline the role of the Forum and transform it into a tool for tangible results, the White Paper advocates a paradigm shift: it is necessary to move from declarations of intent to technicality”, describes Bárbara Morais. The doctoral student suggests “the creation of specialized technical working groups, especially in the technological sphere, and the rigorous definition of performance indicators, such as the number of registered patents, startups created or joint research projects”. “At the same time, it is suggested to establish a common agenda focused on areas of the future, such as green energy, health, the maritime economy and artificial intelligence, subject to a periodic assessment of progress”, he also said. The place of arbitration Taking these meager developments into account, the White Paper suggests that Macau assert itself “as a center for technological arbitration and intellectual property governance”. HM questioned Bárbara Morais about what should be done in effective terms, taking into account the existence, for several years, of an arbitration center, and the fact that it has been a topic on the territory's political agenda for a long time. The doctoral student highlights that “in order for these ideas, debated for years, to stop being rhetoric and become reality, the Macao SAR needs to create a legal framework specialized in technological disputes aligned with the most demanding international standards”. "It is essential to attract international experts and arbitrators through competitive incentives and establish an arbitration center that enjoys recognition both in Portuguese-speaking countries and in the Greater Bay Area. The objective is to develop mediation, certification and management services for intellectual property assets, positioning Macau as a 'safe haven', neutral and efficient, for the resolution of international technological disputes", he added. Unequal cooperation In global terms, and with regard to cooperation between China and Portuguese-speaking Countries (PLP), the White Paper refers to “top planning” by Beijing for cooperation in universities and scientific research. However, planning “does not translate, linearly, into equally effective execution mechanisms on the ground, nor does it guarantee homogeneous results among the nine Portuguese-speaking countries”. Planning implies “clear guidelines, defined priorities and diplomatic instruments mobilized to guide this cooperation”, with policies such as “Made in China 2025” or the “Digital Silk Road”, which “integrate technological cooperation with the PLP into the very core of Chinese foreign policy and national innovation”, highlights the author. However, there are “inequalities, which are perhaps the most striking feature of this relationship”, as Bárbara Morais explains. “The current scenario reveals a profound asymmetry, characterized by a ‘bicephaly’ in cooperation. (…) The main scientific capabilities, the robust technological infrastructure and the volume of effective cooperation are overwhelmingly concentrated in Portugal and Brazil”. On the contrary, “Portuguese-speaking African countries (PALOP) and Timor-Leste have a significantly lower participation”. According to Bárbara Morais, the “disparity does not arise from a lack of political will, but rather from structural funding limitations, a shortage of qualified human resources and the fragility of local research institutions”. Thus, there is “two-speed cooperation, very asymmetrical within the Portuguese-speaking community itself”. The White Paper highlights the “historic crossroads” in relation to cooperation between China and the PLP, which means “the urgent need to move from potential to implementation” in this matter. "There are ambitious visions and strategic plans, but practical results remain below what is possible. To resolve this crossroads, the proposed path involves strengthening execution mechanisms, investing massively in talent and technical-scientific education, creating ecosystems of genuine collaborative innovation between China, Macau and the PLP, and, above all, having the courage to measure results and reformulate strategies based on empirical evidence, abandoning the discourse of circumstance in favor of economic and scientific pragmatism." Gaps in Africa Another of the conclusions of the White Paper is the “tenuity” of academic links with the African continent, which Bárbara Morais describes as a “fragile scenario”. “There is a triad of factors: the scarcity of installed scientific capacity, the chronic lack of funding and consistent mobility programs”, without forgetting “the absence of stable joint research structures”. “To bridge this gap and create a lasting critical mass, the White Paper is not limited to diagnosis, suggesting concrete measures such as the robust reinforcement of research grants, the creation of joint doctoral programs, the implementation of collaborative laboratories and the design of academic mobility mechanisms specifically oriented to the African reality”, he adds. The document also talks about the negative impact of “geopolitical asymmetries”, such as the “technological restrictions of the European Union and NATO on Portugal”. According to Bárbara Morais, “real and restrictive impacts” are at stake. "These limitations condition the participation of Portugal and, by extension, of other Portuguese-speaking actors that cooperate in a network with Lisbon, in high-technology projects that involve China. The impact is particularly sensitive in critical areas such as 5G telecommunications, defense, artificial intelligence and cybersecurity, creating barriers that require complex diplomatic navigation." New strategies The White Paper was developed at the UCM Research Institute on Portuguese-Speaking Countries, and written by Bárbara Morais with the participation of academic João Simões. The project is based on a review of academic literature on the topic and also on the results of the “Technological Cooperation Launch Seminar”, held on July 22, 2025 at UCM. The work analyzes areas such as “strategic evolution”, “institutional mechanisms”, “technological milestones” and “structural challenges”, aiming to “provide evidence-based strategies to transform the potential of the China-PLP partnership into a concrete reality, creating a new model of technological cooperation for the Global South”, says a statement from UCM.

item.title: Australia | Twelve killed in attack during Jewish festival
item.description: At least twelve people died and many injured were transported to Sydney hospitals yesterday, after a shooting attack on the Australian beach of Bondi, while a Jewish celebration was taking place. “There are two people in police custody on Bondi beach”, reported the New South Wales State Police on its X account, which asks “the public to avoid the area”. Citando fontes policiais, a agência de notícias AFP refere que o ataque causou dez mortos. The New South Wales ambulance service confirmed to ABC television that at least 16 people were transported to six hospital centers in the region. Several witnesses report that it was a shooting attack carried out by an as yet undetermined number of armed people, but the authorities have not confirmed this information either. A British tourist told French news agency AFP that he saw “two gunmen dressed in black and armed with semi-automatic rifles”. Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has already issued a statement lamenting the “shocking and distressing scenes” coming from Bondi and confirmed the existence of injuries. Part of the beach was the scene of a celebration of the Jewish festival of Hanukkah, which began yesterday and, although Australian authorities have not yet made any connection with the incident, the President of Israel, Isaac Herzog, denounced what he classified as a “vile terrorist attack against the Jews who were lighting the first candles” of the religious festival. "Our heart is with them. The heart of the entire nation of Israel beats strong at this precise moment, as we pray for the recovery of the injured, we pray for them and we pray for those who lost their lives," he said in an official statement.

item.title: FAOM | Praises casino subsidies, but calls for more measures
item.description: The Federation of Workers' Associations of Macau (FAOM) praised the concessionaires' option to award bonuses to workers, but called for more measures, mainly in terms of reducing long workloads. The position was taken by Choi Kam Fu, vice-president of FAOM. According to statements cited by the newspaper Ou Mun, Choi Kam Fu considered that the gaming concessionaires' bonuses reflect a policy of “sharing the fruits of development” in society, which helps workers feel valued and happy. However, the association leader warned that many concessionaire workers face long periods of work that are having a significant impact on the workers' physical and mental level. Faced with increased pressure to recover the game, Choi Kam Fu called on concessionaires to improve workers' salaries and other benefits, invest more time in training and increase the number of job vacancies, to meet actual needs, instead of forcing current workers to work excessively long shifts.

item.title: Metro | Station opened for just over a year will have new coverage
item.description: The Government and the Macau Light Rail Society justified the intervention at Lótus Station with the need to replace the roof that was damaged due to the passage of a typhoon The Lótus Light Rail Station will undergo renovation work to replace the roof, starting today. The announcement was made on Friday, through a joint statement from the Traffic Affairs Services Department (DSAT) and the Macau Light Rail Company (MLM). In operation since December 2024, just over a year ago, the works were justified by the damage suffered by the roof: “The Sociedade do Metro Ligeiro de Macau, S.A. (MLM) will begin, on January 12th, after the necessary coordination, the work to replace the roof system of the Lotus Station on the Taipa Line, which was previously damaged due to the passage of a typhoon”, it was announced. “The work will include the complete replacement of the station's covering system and the platform's false ceiling, among other works, within a period of 120 working days, in order to improve the waiting environment”, it was added. During the works “parts of the platform will be closed in phases, and the metro will run on the Taipa Line with two-car trains”. However, MLM promises that “during periods of greater affluence, the frequency [of circulation] will be increased to ensure passenger travel needs”. The cost of the intervention at the station, which opened just over a year ago, was not revealed. Road Circulation The impacts of replacing the roof are not limited to the constraints on the circulation of the Light Rail and will also affect the roads close to the station. “On the section of Estrada Flor de Lótus, next to the Lótus Station of the Light Metro (towards the Ponte Flor de Lótus), traffic will be restricted, and the pedestrian passage under the station will be temporarily closed until the work is completed”, it was revealed. “MLM will install fencing, signage and temporary access inside the station, and will deploy additional staff to provide assistance and guidance to passengers,” it was explained. “Additionally, measures will be implemented to control the flow of people, depending on the influx”, it was indicated. The Government and MLM recommend “passengers to pay attention to the information available at the station” and “plan their journeys in advance”. “MLM would like to thank citizens for their understanding of the inconvenience caused during the construction of the work”, it was added.

item.title: Press | All About Macau registration canceled
item.description: The Government announced the cancellation of the registration of the online newspaper and monthly printed publication All About Macau, which in October had announced the closure due to “increasing pressures”. The Executive's Social Communication Office (GCS) said that in 2025 it revoked the registration of six publications, including All About Macau, “in accordance with the applicable provisions of the Press Law and the Press Registration Regulation”. In a statement released on Friday, the GCS did not reveal the reasons for canceling the publications' registrations. A letter sent by GCS to All About Macau in October and cited by the Macau News Agency portal points out the “prolonged absence” of the company owner as the reason for revoking the registration. The Press Law, which dates back to 1990, states that periodical publications “must have at least one person in charge resident in the Macau Special Administrative Region, who will perform the functions of director”. All About Macau ceased operations in December, due to “increasing pressures”, lack of resources and being prevented from accessing places open to the public.

item.title: Consumption | New local Carnival starts today
item.description: Another Carnival of Consumption begins today, this time only centered on the northern part of the peninsula. The initiative that runs until February 20th has different formats. Every purchase over MOP100 entitles you to a weekly draw of discount coupons of up to MOP50. The only accepted electronic payment method is the Bank of China application Another Carnival of Consumption begins today, in an edition dedicated to the northern part of the peninsula and in a different format from the last editions. Over the course of six weeks, until February 20th, anyone who makes purchases worth more than 100 patacas in more than 470 stores participating in the program will be eligible for a weekly draw for three discount coupons with values ​​of 10, 20, 30 and 50 patacas. This time, the only accepted electronic payment platform is the application of the Bank of China, one of the partners in organizing the initiative, along with the Industrial and Commercial Association of the North Zone of Macau. Another difference compared to previous editions is the extension of the period in which coupons can be used, which is now daily, instead of just on weekends. Discounts can be used within a period of 14 days after the draw, for purchases worth double the amount of the coupon, that is, a MOP 10 coupon can be used for a purchase of 20 patacas. When presenting the measure, the president of the Industrial and Commercial Association of the North Zone of Macau, Wong Kin Chong, estimated that participating traders could see an increase in business volume of between 20 and 30 percent. "This is our expectation, as the event will take place before the Lunar New Year. For now, we will award electronic coupons worth one million patacas. This will generate at least two million patacas in transactions, but we hope that the amount can reach 10 million patacas", added the person in charge, according to TDM's Canal Macau. Lucky shots The initiative is still open to the registration of more commercial establishments in the northern part of the peninsula. The organization stressed that once again the measure was designed to stimulate consumption in restaurants and retail in around half of the stores and restaurants in the area. In addition to discount coupons, Wong Kin Chong indicated that some stores and restaurants will run their own promotions to encourage customers. As has been common in previous editions, consumers who participate in the initiative automatically qualify for a draw that takes place at the end of the campaign, which will distribute a car, a motorcycle, cell phones, household appliances, among other prizes.

item.title: Entertainment Zone | Government admits change of purpose
item.description: The Secretary for Social Affairs and Culture, O Lam, admitted, in this Wednesday's debate in the Legislative Assembly (AL), that the Open Air Performance Zone, in Cotai, could host other types of community activities than just concerts. In response to an oral question from deputy Chan Lai Kei, the secretary stated that, after a year of experimental use, the intention is to “expand and reinforce the functions of the venue”, with “the spaces available between concerts being used to transform the venue into 3×3 basketball courts or spaces for family sporting activities”. The Zone will therefore be “a space open to citizens in order to increase flexibility and general benefits of use”. “Regarding the issue raised regarding the introduction of diverse events such as cultural and creative fairs, among others, the Government will maintain an open attitude in the evaluation process”, said the secretary.

item.title: Housing | Chan Lai Kei warns Government of infiltration problems
item.description: Deputy Chan Lai Kei alerted the Government to the needs of residents who have leaks at home and are unable to contact their neighbors to resolve the problem. The matter was addressed through a written interpellation, in which the deputy indicated that there are currently 1,700 buildings in Macau that present structural aging problems. “As both residents and buildings age, water leaks and blocked sewers caused by aging building drainage systems have become persistent problems that bother residents,” the congressman wrote. In view of this situation, the deputy indicates that the Interservice Center for the Treatment of Water Infiltration in Public Administration Buildings received more than 1,900 requests for assistance and information between January and 12 December. “Almost 90 percent were resolved through mediation, but approximately 152 cases remained unresolved as owners failed to comply or cooperate after mediation,” he revealed. “Residents who face water infiltration problems are constantly faced with three major difficulties: obtaining access to the property, carrying out inspections and obtaining compensation”, he warned. The legislator therefore asks the Government to promote a campaign on the obligation of property owners who refuse to cooperate with neighbors to resolve infiltrations. The deputy also asks the Executive to take “preventive” measures to deal with these problems.

item.title: Inquiry | More than half of young people disappointed with salaries
item.description: A survey by the General Women's Association reveals that more than half of young people think salaries are below expectations and a third admit to a lack of professional experience. In terms of training, almost half of those surveyed would like to have more proficiency in languages The Macau General Women's Association yesterday presented a survey focused on youth employment. When looking for a job, or changing professional careers, more than 50 percent of young people surveyed indicated that salaries and benefits are below their expectations. Still on this topic, around 42 percent pointed to high competition as the main challenge, a third confessed to not having relevant professional experience. Another challenge mentioned was the mismatch between skills and the demands of the Macau job market. The mismatch between young people's abilities and work demands, combined with the lack of opportunities to develop advanced skills and the high cost of professional certifications was identified as one of the biggest obstacles to starting a career. When it comes to developing skills, almost half of those surveyed pointed to language training as their preferred choice, followed by what the survey authors called “interpersonal skills” (solving complex problems and negotiating skills). The other skills listed by the young people were management and leadership skills. Lack of space Regarding training actions, the survey by the General Women's Association reveals that almost 50 percent of young people want to access practical courses on digital content (such as Artificial Intelligence and mega-data). On the other hand, around 46 percent would like to attend internationally recognized professional certification courses. Furthermore, more than half of young people stated that Macau's labor market is too small, with no advanced skills development projects or internationally recognized professional training plans. The time and financial cost of this type of training was highlighted as an obstacle to professional progression by more than 37 percent of respondents. In terms of priorities in the labor market, almost 75 percent of respondents indicated that they prioritized wages, the balance between work and free time and job stability. The survey was carried out online, between October and November, among residents aged between 18 and 45, with 568 valid responses. During the presentation of the study results, deputies Wong Kit Cheng and Loi I Weng made recommendations to address the challenges enumerated by young people. The first suggestions were policies that the Government has indicated for years as priorities, such as the construction of the Deep Cooperation Zone between Guangdong and Macau in Hengqin and the adequate diversification of the economy. The deputies also asked for an increase in support for the Training and Accreditation Exams Program for Qualified Personnel to at least 10 thousand patacas.

item.title: Presidential how much do you oblige
item.description: More than 50 years ago, the 25th of April gave us the happiness of having freedom and free elections. Once again, we are faced with the will of the people in choosing a new President of the Republic. The presidential elections, to be held on the 18th, will have more candidates almost than mothers. There are 11 candidates, but incompetently and absurdly the ballot papers will show three more candidates who were rejected by the Constitutional Court (Joana Beatriz Amaral Dias, Luís Ricardo Sousa and José António Cardoso). Voters will have to be very careful not to vote for a candidate who is not in the election. The candidates are, in order of the bulletin: André Pestana, Jorge Pinto, Manuel João Vieira, Catarina Martins, João Cotrim de Figueiredo, Humberto Correia, António José Seguro, Luís Marques Mendes, André Ventura, António Filipe and Henrique Gouveia e Melo. This group of candidates participated in the most disparate and uninteresting television debates. Some of the debates were more like discussions for legislative elections, when the powers of a President of the Republic are absolutely different and negligible in relation to the topics that the candidates debated. There were debates about washing dirty linen and insults. In the last debate, even the people were astonished to see and hear the discussion between Gouveia e Melo and Marques Mendes, two candidates suspected of mediating interests (Marques Mendes) and direct adjustments (Gouveia e Melo. It was, in truth, a sad spectacle that in no way benefited the candidates themselves and the dignity that must be imposed on the behavior of a future head of state. Oh, presidential, how much you oblige. Now, the candidates are spending their last Carthusians throughout the country. And anything goes. Kisses, hugs, markets, gifts and visits to fairs in the search for votes, even if it is in areas that are hostile to them. As has been the case with candidate André Ventura, who wherever he goes and where there are gypsy communities, he only hears insults, some well deserved because this candidate has carried out a policy of aggression towards all gypsies, who have lived in Portugal for much longer than Ventura's age. The street campaign has not been very successful. A few dozen people joining propaganda marches through the cities. Some candidates, such as Marques Mendes, have held rallies behind closed doors, gathering members of the party to which they belong. In the specific case of Marques Mendes, we had something that went down very badly within the PSD itself. The fact that Luís Montenegro went to one of these rallies appealed to vote for Marques Mendes. It was very bad for him, because he forgot that his position as prime minister should lead him to party contention at a time of widespread election campaigning. Ultimately, in an election campaign, anything goes and candidates do not miss opportunities to denigrate their opponents, always using language unfit for consumption. The big surprise of the electoral campaign has fallen on candidates Cotrim de Figueiredo, António José Seguro and Catarina Martins. These have presented a language of statesmen, of seriousness and confidence in the future for the benefit of the lives of the Portuguese, always expressing that if they are elected that cooperation with the Executive will be a reality, but of criticism and presentation of proposals for better governance. It was no coincidence that these three candidates' polls rose. Many left-wing democrats indicate on social media that if António Filipe, Jorge Pinto and Catarina Martins gave up in favor of Seguro, the socialist's victory would be guaranteed. However, it is necessary to remember that if a citizen decided to run for the position of head of the Nation, it was because he understood that, therefore, his conscience had decided and he has nothing to give up, but rather, continue until the 17th of this month to express his convictions and proposals. These presidential elections present a predictable picture of a technical tie between Seguro, Ventura, Melo, Figueiredo and Mendes. Everything indicates that there will be a second round of elections in February with the result of the first two to fall between the five candidates mentioned. However, in around 100 phone calls and messages that we sent to people we knew, the result gave us Gouveia e Melo in first place and António José Seguro in second. Thus, it would be these two candidates who would compete in the second round. The important thing is that Portugal remains in a democratic regime and that we are facing another free electoral act, when voices have been heard that promote a return to neo-fascism. In a week's time we will already know who won the elections and who, in principle, will contest the second round. Vote well!

item.title: Waiting for the light
item.description: There are those who say that when God closes a door, he always opens a window. What if both are closed? What happens to those inside? Well, either they suffocate to death or they get bored to death. In recent years, stores in Macau have been closing one after another. When everyone expected a window to be opened for the business to prosper, the right to open the window was given to certain contractors. Social enterprises are not commercial entities and the outcome of granting them exclusive management of commercial activities is not difficult to predict. If the planning were viable, the operation of the Canídromo Yat Yuen in Macau and the Jockey Club in Taipa should have been handed over to community organizations a long time ago. I recently had dinner at a hotel that once had a casino. I noticed that the hotel's parking lot was abandoned and several floors of this building, which housed several stores, are currently empty. After asking what had happened, I learned that, in addition to the closure of the satellite casino, the Chinese restaurant had also closed. Of course, this hotel is not located in any of the six historical zones defined by the SAR Government. The employees at the satellite casino received new job offers, but what happened to the staff at the Chinese restaurant, who pays attention to their future? I am concerned that while the “diversification of 1+4 industries” is not yet mature, the drastic transformations at the core of Macau's economy will have an impact on the economic structure. Although the unemployment rate is apparently low, the reality of the employment situation deserves attention. Chief Executive Sam Hou Fai encouraged young people to leave their comfort zone and venture to the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area, however, the Greater Bay Area faces its own challenges. Young people from Macau who study outside the city choose to stay there and each one will have their own reasons. The SAR Government claims that it wants to attract talented foreigners to Macau, while encouraging our young people to leave the city, which seems contradictory. Former deputy Lam U Tao even expressed concern about the number of non-resident teachers in Macau, proposing the creation of a mechanism that would lead more than 100,000 non-resident workers to leave the city and “return job vacancies to local workers”. Unfortunately, although Lam passed the government assessment in the 2021 Legislative Assembly elections, he was disqualified for the 2025 elections. When will the “window to democracy” be opened so that residents can breathe fresh air? Looking doesn't kill hunger. I recently visited the renovated Taipa Market and saw that the pedestrian traffic areas are still insufficient. Vegetable, meat and seafood vendors were waiting for customers, in stark contrast to the hustle and bustle of Gongbei Market in Zhuhai. The doors and windows of the Taipa Market were open, but the air (the clientele) was insufficient. Sellers have tried hard, but the results continue to be disappointing. Why does this happen? Is it useful to turn off lights at night and turn them on during the day? I believe that the main people responsible for the SAR Government should leave their comfort zones. At the end of the afternoon, they should take public transport and get off at the stop in front of the Public Administration Building on Rua do Campo and experience the warm feeling of sharing the journey with other passengers. They should also try to cross the border on foot at the Portas do Cerco Border Post and the Qingmao Border Post, in the morning and late afternoon, witnessing the magnificent spectacle of “integration in the Great Bay”. With numerous advertisements saying “excellent store for rent” in various areas of Macau, how can the lights be on after they have been turned off? The development of an urban area and the formation of a commercial area cannot be achieved simply by turning on the lights, they require collective wisdom.

item.title: Venezuela and the New World Geopolitics
item.description: “Power reshapes the world not only through action, but through the precedents it gives to create.” – Henry Kissinger The United States' military intervention in Venezuela, on January 3, 2026, cannot be understood simply as a gesture of strength in a weakened country but must be read as an event that exposes the structural tension between sovereignty, responsibility and power in a world in transition. The operation, carried out with almost surgical precision, was limited to extracting Nicolás Maduro and Cilia Flores from Caracas and transporting them to New York, where they face a judicial process that quickly went beyond the criminal sphere to become a political, philosophical and legal phenomenon of global reach. The absence of territorial occupation, provisional administration or any attempt to reorganize the Venezuelan State for now reveals a doctrine that breaks with the interventionist paradigm of the beginning of the 21st century in which the United States does not seek to rebuild countries, only to neutralize sources of threat, leaving behind the political void that inevitably forms when a regime loses its center of gravity. This void was filled by Delcy Rodríguez, whose rise is not the result of any popular mandate, but of the inertia of a state machine that, long ago, stopped functioning as a republican institution and began to operate as an instrument of survival for an exhausted political project. Its legitimacy is purely mechanical, derived from Chavismo's internal line of succession, and not from the will expressed at the polls, which in 2024 gave Edmundo González Urrutia a mandate that he never exercised. Maduro's extraction did not dissolve the networks that supported the regime; he just removed the figure that gave them faces. Delcy inherited a corroded state, but functional enough to maintain the appearance of normality, while the underground military, economic and criminal structures continue to operate with the same logic that transformed Venezuela into a narco state. The trial in New York became a legal laboratory that challenges traditional categories of international law. The invocation of universal jurisdiction for transnational crimes committed by a head of state, albeit illegitimate, captured by military means puts into tension principles that, for decades, seemed unquestionable. Sovereign immunity, designed to protect the stability of international relations, confronts the idea that certain crimes, due to their nature, cannot be shielded by functional prerogatives. The defense will argue that the capture violates fundamental norms, while the prosecution will maintain that the seriousness of the alleged facts justifies the exception. The court will become the stage for a dispute that goes beyond the individual destiny of the accused and touches on the very balance between sovereignty, responsibility and power. The global transmission of the process will amplify every gesture and word, converting the trial into a political event that redefines conceptual boundaries. The legal discussion inevitably refers to historical precedents that shaped the contemporary understanding of individual criminal responsibility. The trial of Eichmann, captured in Buenos Aires and taken to Jerusalem in 1961, is often cited as an example that extraterritorial capture, although controversial, does not necessarily invalidate the legitimacy of the process. The doctrine that emerged from that case with the idea that certain crimes are so serious that they transcend borders is echoed in the current debate. However, the comparison has limits as Eichmann was a fugitive without official status, while Maduro was head of state at the time of his capture, which reactivates the discussion about functional and personal immunities. The Pinochet case, partially tried in the United Kingdom, introduced another fissure in the traditional legal edifice by admitting that crimes of torture cannot be protected by sovereign immunity. International jurisprudence has evolved since then, but remains fragmented, oscillating between the defense of sovereignty and the affirmation of an international legal order that holds individuals accountable regardless of their position. Venezuela, however, remains suspended between two periods. The democratic opposition, although legitimized by the vote, remains far from exercising power. Edmundo González Urrutia, exiled in Spain, became a symbol of a legitimacy that exists internationally, but not in the territory he should govern. María Corina Machado, reappeared after the fall of Maduro, regained internal protagonism, but faces a structural obstacle, that the formal State is only the visible surface of a parallel system, where criminal networks, military interests and informal alliances shape political reality. The opposition has legitimacy, but does not control the territory; it has international support, but it does not have the coercive instruments that define effective power. The Venezuelan military structure, far from being dismantled by the American operation, remains fragmented and permeated by contradictory loyalties. Maduro's extraction neutralized only the closest circle, leaving intact a hierarchy eroded by decades of politicization, corruption and involvement in illicit economies. Many senior officers maintain links with networks that operate outside the legality, while intermediate sectors seek to reposition themselves to guarantee their own survival. The absence of broader institutional intervention allowed the narco state to continue to function, now under the leadership of Delcy Rodríguez, who is trying to reorganize Chavismo without its historical leader, preserving the informal mechanisms that guarantee the continuity of power. The Venezuelan economy, devastated by years of mismanagement and hyperinflation, remains in a state of structural collapse. PDVSA, once a symbol of prosperity, operates far below its capacity, and the global fall in oil prices further reduces financial room for maneuver. Maduro's extraction did not change this reality. Without deep reforms, political transition and international trust, the economy remains paralyzed. The criminalization of the political economy impedes any sustainable recovery, as illicit networks capture revenues, distort incentives, and block any attempt at institutional reconstruction. Venezuela has become an extreme case of a state where the formal economy is just a residual fragment of a system dominated by parallel circuits. The Portuguese community, one of the largest Portuguese-speaking diasporas outside Europe, lives in an environment of permanent uncertainty. Political instability, the lack of reforms and the continuity of criminal networks create significant risks, but also opportunities if a minimum of predictability emerges. Portugal can play a relevant role through reinforced consular protection and economic diplomacy, but any initiative will depend on the country's internal developments. At the international level, the American operation reinforced the tendency to replace multilateralism with surgical unilateral actions. The lack of coordination with international organizations weakened traditional alliances and intensified rivalries with emerging powers, in a context in which Russia and China had responded with military demonstrations in the Caribbean and the Persian Gulf to signal that they contest the power projection of the United States and intend to preserve their influence in a hemisphere historically sensitive to external intervention. Venezuela has thus become a microcosm of the new global order; a space where strategic disputes, legal tensions and conflicts of legitimacy intersect. The country's future will depend on the interaction between internal and external factors, now profoundly changed by Delcy Rodríguez's cooperation with Washington and the increasing control of the oil sector by the Americans. Between 2026 and 2030, four main trajectories can be outlined. The first is the consolidation under the tutelage of Delcy Rodríguez, which not only represents the continuity of Chavismo, but rather the adaptation of the regime to a new geopolitical reality. Cooperation with the United States transforms Chavismo into a partially domesticated system, where the narco state continues to operate, but within externally imposed limits. Stability becomes dependent on American tolerance, the relative discipline of the Armed Forces and the regime's ability to redistribute oil rents under implicit surveillance. It is not a sovereign stability, but a stability under guardianship, in which Caracas governs while Washington defines the perimeter of the possible. The second trajectory is the agreed transition, now reconfigured by the centrality of oil. It is no longer just a controlled exit in exchange for personal guarantees for sectors of Chavismo, but a political-energy negotiation in which Washington accepts a gradual opening and institutional recomposition as long as it maintains decisive influence over the oil sector. Delcy becomes the bridge between the system and the transition, offering Americans energy predictability and Chavismo guarantees of partial survival. Political change would be limited but real, and would allow controlled pluralism under international supervision. The third trajectory is the implosion of the system, now aggravated by oil cooperation itself. Shared management of the energy sector could deepen internal fissures, especially between the military, criminal networks and ideological factions that see approaching the United States as betrayal. Economic deterioration, inequality in the redistribution of income and competition for resources under external supervision can accelerate the fragmentation of the State, creating enclaves of autonomous power and multiplying armed actors. In this scenario, energy protection does not prevent implosion; amplified, by introducing new reasons for dispute and distrust. The fourth trajectory is the possibility of a second American intervention, now more plausible precisely because oil cooperation creates an evaluation criterion. If, despite energy control, Chavismo reorganized under Delcy continues to operate as a narco state and no substantive political transformation occurs, Washington may conclude that the extraction of Maduro was insufficient. The new intervention would not necessarily imply territorial occupation, but could take surgical forms such as the neutralization of specific military actors, blocking of illicit financial networks, additional operations against security structures or even a multinational intervention legitimized by extreme humanitarian collapse. The mere existence of this hypothesis weakens the first trajectory, as Delcy's consolidation would only be sustainable in an international environment willing to tolerate the continuity of Chavismo, which is becoming increasingly less likely. Thus, Venezuela remains in a political and institutional limbo without Maduro, but with Chavismo; with functional administration, but without legitimacy; with oil cooperation with the United States, but without full sovereignty. Maduro's extraction and oil co-management did not end the cycle; they just reshaped the battlefield. Reconstruction will require inclusive dialogue, profound reform and an international commitment to legality. Until then, the country remains suspended between the end of a regime that does not exist and the impossibility of a future that has not yet begun.

item.title: Homo Sapiens versus “Goldilocks Conditions”
item.description: Around 13.8 billion years ago, what is known as the “big bang” occurred. From this great explosion an expanding universe emerged, which is essentially made up of dark energy, dark matter, gases, dust, planets and stars. These grouped together to form galaxies, in one of which, the Milky Way, our planet is located, fortunately very far away, around 25,800 light years, from the black hole that occupies the central area. By happy chance, during the evolution of the universe, planet Earth, which was formed about 4.5 billion years ago, occupied an ideal position to create the conditions for life to emerge. The first signs of life are due to the existence of oxygen in the atmosphere and hydrosphere, and to the Earth orbiting around the Sun at a distance that allows it to receive radiation whose intensity can be considered neither excessive nor lacking. Thus, the first species of beings emerged that evolved, giving rise to hundreds of thousands of other species that adapted to climate variations. The climate system has, however, undergone changes due to several factors, namely cosmic and volcanic in origin. Cosmic factors include the variation in solar activity and the Milankovitch cycles, which consist of changes in the orbit around the Sun, related to the eccentricity, obliquity and oscillation of the Earth's axis. The action of these and other factors resulted in climate changes, including those that caused the ice ages and interglacials. The conditions favorable to the existence of life on our planet are commonly referred to, in circles related to astronomy and astrobiology, as “Goldilocks conditions”, which could be translated as “golden snail conditions”, so called by analogy with the children's story “Goldilocks and the three bears”, very popular in English-speaking countries, written by Robert Southey (1774-1843). In this story, a girl with golden curls always chose the middle ground as the best option among the possibilities that came across her throughout her mischief. For example, between three plates of porridge, one very hot, one very cold and one lukewarm, I would choose the lukewarm one, or between three beds I would prefer the one that was neither too hard nor too soft, but moderately soft. When applied to astronomy, this concept metaphorically refers to a habitable zone in the universe. In reality, even though there may be other planets with conditions similar to those on Earth, it will not be possible, at least in the next few decades, to reach them and create the conditions so that our civilization can survive in the event of a collapse of living conditions on our planet. We must therefore take care of the Earth's climate system. Otherwise, mass extinctions of species could occur. This has already happened five times and there are those who claim that we are facing the sixth extinction, due to human activities, with special emphasis on climate change, pollution, destruction of habitats and unrestrained exploitation of natural resources. Currently, no significant trend has been detected regarding cosmic factors that could alter these “Goldilocks conditions”. However, when it comes to human behavior, the reality is that, if we do not curb the indiscriminate use of fossil fuels, we are causing a significant increase in global warming. Humanity is not ensuring that these conditions persist, given that our planet has been warming since the beginning of the industrial era, at a rate never observed before, which causes the degradation of the various components of the climate system. And the near future does not look bright, as the country that emits the most greenhouse gases has at its head an irresponsible government that continues to ignore the warnings of institutions responsible for monitoring climate change and ensuring the sustainability of our planet. Worse than that, it has been taking measures contrary to these recommendations, such as, for example, withdrawing from the Paris Agreement, dismissing scientists from organizations that deal with the atmosphere and oceans, or cutting funding to universities where research related to climate change is carried out. Finally, a list of measures that could contribute to the deterioration of the climate system, thus posing a threat to life on our planet. The worst thing is that, as the former Secretary-General of the United Nations, Kofi Annan, stated, “there is no planet B”. But, one might ask, «what does all this have to do with these “Goldilocks conditions”?». In reality, the changes that the climate has undergone and which are estimated to have caused, in the last four hundred and fifty million years, some of the five mass extinctions of living beings, took place over thousands of years. It is commonly accepted by paleontologists and paleoclimatologists that the greater or lesser concentration of carbon dioxide was one of the causes of climate change that was the basis for most mass extinctions. Only one of the great extinctions, that of dinosaurs and other species of megafauna, is not directly related to climate, but rather due to the impact of an asteroid with Earth, around 66 million years ago. The big difference between the climate changes of thousands of years ago and the changes that the climate is currently undergoing is the fact that those changes occurred slowly, over thousands of years, while the current ones have only been occurring since the beginning of the industrial revolution, that is, for around two and a half hundred years. According to cosmologist Stephen Hawking (1942–2018), “Like Goldilocks, the development of intelligent life requires that planetary temperatures be ‘just right'”. Inspired by this statement from someone who has studied the evolution of the universe in depth, we can only contribute to ensuring that these “Goldilocks conditions” continue to be fulfilled. Luis Queirós (1) will certainly forgive me for using the calculations contained in his book “Humanity and the Future” to highlight how recent the appearance of Homo sapiens is, in relation to the appearance of the first signs of life, between 3 billion and 4 billion years ago. Abandoning periods on a geological scale, which are difficult to grasp, and resorting to matching an intermediate value, for example 3.6 billion years, to 40 hours, Homo sapiens would have appeared only in the last fifteen seconds. Let me add that, maintaining this correspondence, the approximately 250 years since the industrial revolution correspond to 0.012 seconds. Let us hope that in the next few thousandths of a second Homo sapiens will curb the use of fossil fuels and carry out an effective energy transition, taking measures to halt and reverse global warming, ensuring that “Goldilocks conditions” continue to protect us. (Meteorologist) (1) Luis Queirós – author of “The World in Transition” and “Humanity and the Future”. Founder of the Marktest Group, a pioneering entity in market research in Portugal. He established the “Fundação Vox Populi” and created the blog “Transição”.

item.title: Monte Fortress | Exhibition celebrates restoration of the Mogao Caves
item.description: From next Friday, the 16th, it will be possible to get to know more about the Mogao Caves, in Dunhuang, China, classified by UNESCO and which, over the last hundred years, have been the target of successive restoration actions, taking into account the importance of their architectural, cultural and historical heritage. The “Dunhuang Caves Restoration Centenary Exhibition” will be available at the Monte Fortress gallery From Friday the 16th, the Fortaleza do Monte gallery hosts an exhibition on one of China's great monuments, classified by UNESCO. This is the “Exhibition of the Centenary of the Restoration of the Dunhuang Caves”, more specifically the Mogao Caves. The exhibition is supported by the Cultural Institute (IC) and organized by the Macau Heritage Studies Association and the Association of Friends of Culture of Dunhuang of Macau. The inauguration takes place at 6:30 pm. According to a note released on social media by the Macau Heritage Studies Association, this exhibition aims to present to the public “the work to protect the Dunhuang caves over the last hundred years, one of the only two sites worldwide that meets all six criteria of World Cultural Heritage [by UNESCO], and is also the largest and best preserved sanctuary of Buddhist cave art in the world”. According to the same note, “since their discovery, the Mogao Caves have received great attention from the public, and, over more than a century, various efforts have been made to protect this precious heritage”. Currently, according to the association, “the conservation of the Mogao Caves has become an exemplary model for the protection of cultural heritage, serving as a reference for learning and jointly safeguarding our cultural heritage”. Great treasure According to the UNESCO portal, the Mogao Caves are located “at a strategic point along the Silk Road, at the crossroads of commercial, religious, cultural and intellectual influences”, containing 492 cells and sanctuaries, as well as sculptures and wall paintings, “which span a thousand years of Buddhist art”. "Carved into the cliffs above the Dachuan River, southeast of the Dunhuang oasis, in Gansu province, the Mogao Caves constitute the largest, most richly endowed and longest-used treasure trove of Buddhist art in the world. Its construction began in 366 AD, representing an extraordinary achievement of Buddhist art between the 4th and 14th centuries. Currently, 492 caves are preserved, housing approximately 45,000 square meters of murals and more than 2,000 painted sculptures”, UNESCO further describes. It is a heritage complex that testifies to “the evolution of Buddhist art in northwest China”, possessing “an incomparable historical value”. For UNESCO, the Mogao Caves “provide abundant visual material on diverse aspects of the politics, economy, culture, arts, religion, ethnic relations and everyday clothing of western medieval China”. The Mogao Caves were discovered in 1900, and include a library area and “tens of thousands of manuscripts and relics”, being described as “the world’s greatest discovery of ancient Eastern culture”. One of the six criteria mentioned by the Macau Heritage Studies Association is the fact that “the group of Mogao Caves represents a unique artistic achievement, both due to the organization of the space in 492 caves spread over five levels, and the creation of more than 2,000 painted sculptures and around 45,000 square meters of murals, among which there are numerous masterpieces of Chinese art”, points out UNESCO. Another criterion concerns a historical issue, namely the fact that “for a thousand years, from the period of the Northern Wei dynasty (386–534) to the Yuan dynasty of Mongol rule (1276–1386), the Mogao Caves played a decisive role in artistic exchanges between China, Central Asia and India”. Furthermore, there is a third criterion, related to the cave paintings, which “constitute an exceptional testimony to the civilizations of ancient China during the Sui, Tang and Song dynasties”. A fourth criterion is linked to the “Groats of a Thousand Buddhas”, which constitute “a notable example of a Buddhist rock art sanctuary”. The fifth criterion concerns the occupation of the caves by Buddhist monks “from the end of the 19th century until 1930”, with the “Mogao rock art group, administered by the Dunhuang Cultural Relics Research Institute, preserving the example of a traditional monastic settlement”. The sixth and final UNESCO criterion for this classification involves the caves being “strongly associated with the history of transcontinental relations and the spread of Buddhism throughout Asia”. “For centuries, the Dunhuang oasis, close to the bifurcation of the two branches of the Silk Road, benefited from the status of a transit station where not only goods were exchanged, but also ideas, as demonstrated by the Chinese, Tibetan, Sogdian, Khotan, Uyghur and even Hebrew manuscripts found in the caves”, it is described.

item.title: Macau Tower | Show celebrates Sino-Portuguese culture
item.description: A new theatrical show takes the stage tomorrow to explore how 500 years of contact between Portuguese and Chinese cultures gave Macau “a unique identity”. In the third edition of the “Macasaphis” series, the experimental theater group Frost Ice Snow Creative brings together music, theater, fashion, oral stories and stand-up comedy in the Macau Tower auditorium. The director, Sileas Ko Weng Si, told Lusa yesterday that, after a two-year break due to lack of funding, the group decided to return with the theme “Sino-Portuguese culture”. "Sino-Portuguese culture is everywhere, but we don't even realize it anymore. People often get confused, without understanding how it influences our lives", explained Sileas Ko. The first edition of “Macasahpis”, in 2022, had already been dedicated to particular elements of the region. “The presence of the Chinese and Portuguese languages, the historical monuments, the fact that we have the largest number of holidays in the world, both Buddhist and Catholic,” said Ko. Portuguese is one of the two official languages ​​of Macau, at least during the first 50 years of the new semi-autonomous Chinese region, according to the bilateral agreement that allowed the transition of administration in December 1999. The 2023 edition had as guests Tuna Macaense, a musical group from the Eurasian community, made up mainly of Portuguese descendants, who play songs in the Creole dialect, Patuá. But this time the group decided to go further and celebrate how Portuguese influence is also felt among the Chinese in Macau, the show's producer, Casta Lai Chit, told Lusa. “Maybe people still feel some shame in defining our culture and identity, because we are Chinese, but we are not the same as others”, explained Casta Lai, who has Portuguese nationality. “People are proud of Macau’s culture, but they have some shame in showing it”, lamented Sileas Ko. "Sino-Portuguese culture makes our city even more special. Without it, there would only be casinos", he added. Cultural power With an area of ​​just 33 square kilometers and less than 680 thousand inhabitants, Macau “is a tiny fish” in the context of China, with a population of 1.4 billion, Casta Lai highlighted. “If it weren’t for Sino-Portuguese culture, Macau wouldn’t be important at all,” argued the producer. The show includes a part in which, in a humorous way, the population of Macau is treated as “an endangered species” and not just because the city has the lowest birth rate in the world, said Sileas Ko. Casta Lai warned that "maybe after 50 years the culture will be different. If that happens, maybe people will look around and miss what was lost."

item.title: First retrospective of Portuguese artist Helena Almeida in Asia opens on the 23rd
item.description: The Macau Museum of Art (MAM) will open the first retrospective of Portuguese artist Helena Almeida (1934-2018) in Asia on January 23, announced one of the exhibition's curators. The exhibition “Helena Almeida: I'm Here – Presença and Resonance” is “one of the most comprehensive ever presented” and will be on display until April 26, Margarida Saraiva said on social media. The MAM curator stated that the retrospective will be divided into five sections, “chronologically and thematically”, including one dedicated to the first paintings and another to “the body as sculpture and the dialogue between bodies”. Saraiva named Helena Almeida as “one of the most relevant Portuguese and European artists of her generation”, who “transformed the act of self-representation into an intense exploration of the body, space, resilience and impermanence”. “His performative gestures — captured only through the lens of his studio — continue to challenge and expand the limits of painting, drawing and photography,” explained the curator. “This exhibition is simultaneously a tribute to Helena Almeida’s extraordinary legacy and an affirmation of the power of curatorial collaboration between cultures”, argued Saraiva. The retrospective's main curator is Delfim Sardo, professor at the University of Coimbra and author of the book “Helena Almeida, Pés no Chão, Cabeça no Céu”, and the Chinese Song Zhen as co-curator. Divide by two In December, the Macau Cultural Institute indicated in a statement that the exhibition will bring together around 42 sets made up of 190 pieces by the Portuguese artist. Another part of the exhibition, “Resonância – Corpo. Objecto. Reflexão”, was opened on December 19, with pieces by six artists from Macau and mainland China, invited to interact with the work of Helena Almeida. Born in Lisbon in 1934, Helena Almeida created, from the 1960s onwards, a multifaceted work, giving rise to a work that stood out for its self-representation, reflecting on the tension relationships between the body, space and the work. He used his body as a support and creative object, using painting, photography, engraving, installation and video. Helena Almeida studied painting at the Escola Superior de Belas-Artes in Lisbon, beginning to exhibit individually in 1967, at Galeria Buchholz. The artist represented Portugal at the Venice Biennale on two occasions: in 1982 and 2005, and in 2004 she participated in the Sydney Biennale, with her work being exhibited in individual and collective exhibitions in national and international museums and galleries. In 2015, he presented a traveling solo exhibition Corpus at Fundação de Serralves (2015), in Porto, in Paris (2016), in Brussels (2016) and Valencia (2017). In 2017, he also presented a solo exhibition “Work is never finished” at the Art Institute, in Chicago, in the United States. His work is present in Portuguese and international collections such as: Berardo Collection, Lisbon; Calouste Gulbenkian Foundation, Lisbon; Serralves Foundation, Porto; Hara Museum of Contemporary Art, Tokyo; Barcelona Museum of Contemporary Art; Museo Nacional Centro de Arte Reina Sofía, Madrid; MUDAM – Musée d’Art Moderne Grand-Duc Jean, Luxembourg; Tate Modern, London.

item.title: Boi Warehouse | Three artists present visions of Macau on display
item.description: “Land and Sea” is the new exhibition hosted by Armazém do Boi and which opens to the public tomorrow. Featuring works by David Fank, this exhibition is the result of the artist's personal experiences in the Greater Bay Area, including cities such as Macau, Zhuhai and Guangzhou. Also noteworthy are the exhibitions by Yuan Zeqiang and Fan Xianxin A new exhibition opens tomorrow at Armazém do Boi. This is “Land and Sea”, written by David Fank, and which can be seen until February. According to a note from Armazém do Boi, the exhibition is divided into two main installations, with the themes of “Earth” and “Sea”, revealing an “exhibition space built like a room where blue and green meet, serving as the artist’s version of a ‘map'” It is in this type of map that the artist's “personal travel experiences” through the Greater Bay Area are shown, namely in places such as Macau, Zhuhai and Guangzhou, without forgetting Beijing. The public can see “an interpretation of these diverse geographic perspectives”, in which David Fank creates “actions such as walks, photography and objects that anchor and generate this map”. “These crystallize in his understanding of the meanings behind these spaces and, naturally, in the change of these meanings – the artist’s gaze and associations, in a sense as an ‘outsider’, thus become manifest”, he further explains. Tomorrow, Wang Jing will give an introduction to the exhibition, starting at 4pm, with “Land and Sea” being the result of an artistic residency carried out by David Fank at Armazém do Boi, namely with the “Artistic Residency Program 3+0/1+1 (Macau / Project 2025)”. David Fank was born in 1984, has a degree and master's degree from the Higher School of Fine Arts in Paris and also a doctorate from the Central Academy of Fine Arts in Beijing, China. He works mainly with photography, installation and sculpture. The stone as origin Another exhibition that can also be seen at Armazém do Boi starting tomorrow is “Seak Kam Tong”, by Yuan Zeqiang, curated by Hu Bin. This exhibition is also the result of the same artistic residency program that hosted the work of David Fank. Here, Yuan Zeqiang establishes a relationship between art and stone, and in turn with the territory itself. “The relationship with stone begins the moment you enter Macau: under your feet, you have a mosaic stone floor”, which includes the Portuguese sidewalk, in addition to “the Temple of A-Má was built on a rocky hill, having become a place where residents and visitors turn for spiritual support”. This exhibition presents “three-dimensional collages that reveal the dualities and truths of modern life”, where Yuan Zeqiang explores the different dimensions, perspectives and meanings of stones in a territory like Macau. "The Portuguese sidewalk, made of fragmented stone, in Macau is a legacy of Portuguese colonial history, and this homogeneous material environment seems to reflect the clash and fusion of multiple cultures in the city. In everyday life, stone appears as a ubiquitous landscape element, something particularly evident in Macau", said Yuan Zeqiang, quoted in the same note. Relationship with the sea Still at Armazém do Boi, the public can see “Standing Wave Manifold”, by Fan Xianxin, curated by Sun Xiaoyu, which explores Macau's relationship with water and the way in which the territory was built with permanent mutations. "'Sea-Mirror' is one of the many names that Macau has had throughout its history. This image refers to a state of immobilization located in a specific time and space. In this city surrounded by water, the border between water and land has been continuously reconstructed since the 19th century to the present day, and the evolution of denominations has occurred together with the changing trajectories of systems, power and identity", of the territory itself, explains a note about the exhibition. The artist, who also completed a period of artistic residency at Armazém do Boi, analyzes Macau “from observations and travels”, trying to “understand how systems, landscapes and Feng Shui act together in shaping our concrete and detailed daily lives”. This exhibition presents concepts such as “standing waves” and “varieties” that are not only physical, but reveal “dynamic equilibrium structures that are formed with the interference of two waves that go in opposite directions, but that constitute a method to interpret the modernization process in Macau”. In this way, we try to understand “the complex totality that is woven by countless fragments, all of them interconnected”. Thus, “Standing Wave Manifold” focuses on the search for investigation “of a ‘mobility’ structure built from ‘movement'”, it is described.

item.title: Health | 480 requests for support for assisted procreation received
item.description: Since the Government launched the Medically Assisted Procreation Treatment Participation Program, in December 2024, until November last year, the Health Services (SS) received 480 requests from residents, said the director of Health Services, Alvis Lo, in response to a written inquiry signed by Leong Sun Iok. In the same period of time, Alvis Lo revealed that 352 couples were referred to the Macau Union Medical Center's outpatient infertility consultation, of which “around 130 cases are able to receive the services of in vitro fertilization technique or intracytoplasmic sperm injection technique”. Regarding access to this type of health care, the director of the SS indicated that, from October 2025, these services will be available, gradually, with the aim that all eligible cases can be attended to within the first half of 2026. Alvis Lo added that “the Macau Union Medical Center has allocated 16 workers, including doctors, laboratory analysis technicians and nursing professionals, among others, to support assisted procreation services”. Currently, subsidies cover expenses for oocyte retrieval and embryo transfer in two cycles (each cycle includes an oocyte retrieval surgery and an embryo transfer). However, the SS director stressed that the program “is still in an initial phase of implementation”, but that in the future it could be reviewed after an assessment of its effectiveness.

item.title: ONE | First public medical college will have 4,000 students
item.description: The Faculty of Medicine is part of the new campus of the University of Macau, under construction since December 12, in the Guangdong-Macao In-depth Cooperation Zone The University of Macau (UM) announced that the first faculty of medicine, created in collaboration with the University of Lisbon (ULisboa), will have 4,000 students. In a statement, UM said that the future Faculty of Medicine will be created through the expansion of the current Faculty of Health Sciences, with the aim of “becoming a world-class medical school”. The new faculty will include departments of Pharmaceutical Sciences and Nutrition, Dental Medicine and Clinical Medicine, the latter with a joint program developed with ULisboa, UM said on Friday. “Building on the Faculty of Medicine’s experience in international joint programs, UM will expand collaborative programs with world-renowned universities in the areas of information science, engineering and design,” the note added. The university is committed to attracting international students, recruiting high-level talent for teaching and research, building international platforms for scientific and technological exchange, hosting major international conferences and supporting the development of academic journals. The Faculty of Medicine is part of the new UM campus, whose construction began on December 12, in the Guangdong-Macao Deep Cooperation Zone, on the neighboring island of Montanha. Three-year construction The new campus will occupy 376,000 square meters in the special economic zone and construction is expected to take three years, with partial opening scheduled for 2028 and construction completion in 2029. Four new faculties will be created in Hengqin, including Information Sciences, Design and Engineering, as well as Macau's first public medical faculty. The Macau University of Science and Technology, a private institution, has had a Faculty of Health Sciences since 2008, officially renamed the Faculty of Medicine in 2019. In June, the director of the Faculty of Medicine at ULisboa told Lusa that doctors trained at the future Faculty of Medicine at UM will also be able to practice in Portugal. ULisboa is collaborating with UM to create a curriculum with a structure “close to the structure” of courses at the Portuguese institution, said Luís Graça. In December, the vice-rector of UM, Rui Martins, said that the new campus will focus on "'dual degrees' [courses in co-tutelship] with foreign universities. Medicine is already with Lisbon and now we are defining it for the other faculties". The new campus in Hengqin should allow UM to expand from its current 15,000 students to a maximum of 25,000 students, highlighted the vice-rector for Global Affairs, in an interview with the Portuguese-language channel of local public television TDM.

item.title: Tourism | Prices rose 1.7 percent last year
item.description: In 2025, the average Tourist Price Index (IPT) rose 1.71 percent, compared to 2024, mainly due to the increase in prices for jewelry and entertainment and leisure. Data released by the Statistics and Census Services show a reduction in the price of hotel rooms. Last year, analysis of “miscellaneous goods”, such as jewelry, watches and handicrafts, shows a price increase of 13.46 percent. In relation to “fun and cultural activities” the annual increase was 8.2 percent. However, the accommodation price index showed a reduction of 2.88 percent, as did the price index for medicines and personal goods with a decrease of 1.93 percent.
