In the fourth quarter of 2025, the IPT grew 4.95 percent, in annual terms, driven by the rise in prices for jewelry (17.33 percent), hotel rooms (7.33 percent) and airline tickets (6.05 percent).

item.title: Windsor Arch | Court refuses confiscation of 264 apartments
item.description: The housing units were built outside the project and correspond to almost 30 percent of the built area. Instead of accepting the confiscation, the TJB held William Kuan Wai Lam, Ng Kei Nin and Ng Lap Seng responsible for paying the value of the apartments to the Macao SAR The Base Judicial Court (TJB) refused the confiscation of 264 of the 265 apartments in the Windsor Arch housing complex that were in the process of being declared property of the Macao SAR. The information was provided by Canal Macau on Friday. According to information disseminated, the TJB refused to confiscate the 264 units, which had since been sold, as it understood that the fairest option was for some of those convicted in the Public Works case to pay the value of the apartments to Macao. The court identified convicts William Kuan Wai Lam, Ng Kei Nin and Ng Lap Seng as responsible for the payments, the amount of which will only be defined later, during the execution process. The apartments are at the center of the controversy because they were built “outside the project area”, despite representing practically 30 percent of the entire housing project. However, when the Ou Mun newspaper first-hand reported the intention to proceed with the confiscation of the apartments, it also indicated that the affected owners, who claimed to be unaware of the illegalities, had resorted to legal advice to avoid losing the apartments. Currently, Ng Lap Seng and Ng Kei Lin, son of the first businessman, are free, after having served, in the context of the Public Works case, prison sentences of four and a half and two years, respectively. Wiliam Kuan is still in Coloane Prison, serving a sentence of five years and six months, but is expected to be released later this year. Public Works Case The Windsor Arch project came under judicial scrutiny as part of the case that resulted in the sentencing of Jaime Carion and Li Canfeng, former directors of Public Works, to prison sentences. According to the Public Prosecutor's Office's indictment, the government officials will have received patrimonial advantages, through their families, to approve construction licenses for different projects, including the Windsor Arch, promoted by William Kuan and Ng Lap Seng. Jaime Carion facilitated the approval of the project, whose characteristics, dimensions and height differed from those stipulated in the concession contract and in the urban plans for the area. In this case, the MP alleged that Carion acted in concert with his, at the time, number two at DSSOPT, Li Canfeng, pressuring technicians from the services they directed to give the green light to several proposed changes to the original project. Carion was tried in absentia and sentenced to 16 years in prison, for six crimes of money laundering and five crimes of passive corruption for an illicit act. Li Canfeng was sentenced to 17 years in prison for five crimes of passive corruption for an illicit act, four of money laundering, one of forgery of documents, one of abuse of power and four of inaccurate information.

item.title: Study | Companies plan fewer and smaller increases
item.description: Around 76.76 percent of companies intend to increase workers' salaries throughout this year, according to a study carried out by MSS Recruitment and Hello Jobs. The survey was carried out among 99 local companies and shows that compared to last year's results there are fewer companies available to increase workers. The 2025 survey results showed that 83.87 percent of companies surveyed had plans to increase headcount. In the space of a year, there are also more companies that have avoided any salary increase. The most recent results show that 23.23 percent of companies surveyed have no intention of applying increases. In 2025, only 16.13 percent of companies did not plan raises. Not only are there fewer companies planning to raise salaries, but increases will also shrink throughout this year. According to conclusions from MSS Recruitment and Hello Jobs, increases throughout 2026 are expected to occur at an average of 2.23 percent of salary. Last year, companies were aiming for average increases of 2.72 percent. The survey also questioned companies about the value of the bonus and concluded that it will remain equivalent to a monthly salary, which shows no changes compared to the previous year.

item.title: IPIM | 13 plan applications received for international companies
item.description: The Macau Trade and Investment Promotion Institute announced that it received 13 applications in the first two months of a program launched to attract international companies to the Macao SAR. More than 500 companies requested information about the support plan The Macau Trade and Investment Promotion Institute (IPIM) revealed in a statement, released on Wednesday, that it had received 13 applications for the “Plan for Economic Development within the scope of Support for the Establishment of the First Store in Macau”, opened in November last year. The entity added that it is analyzing applications to grant “financial support in accordance with budgetary capacity and public interest”. The Economic Development Plan within the scope of Support for the Establishment of the First Store in Macau provides support of up to one million patacas. To receive maximum support, companies must follow certain requirements, such as establishing themselves in NAPE, Areia Preta, Iao Hon, San Kio area, Praia do Manduco, Fai Chi Kei, Doca do Lam Mau, Bairro de Tamagnini Barbosa or Ilha Verde. Furthermore, they must have a minimum area, as well as a certain number of full-time local employees. IPIM also highlighted that more than 500 companies requested information about the program, which was launched on November 1st. The plan lasts three years and has six application phases, the first of which runs until the end of January. At the end of November, the institute's president, Che Weng Keong, said in the Legislative Assembly that among the companies that requested more information about the plan were “brands from Portugal”. IPIM recalled that it “took the initiative” to contact entities in mainland China, Southeast Asia and Portuguese and Spanish speaking countries. Harvest fruits The program, which aims to “enrich the tourist charm of Macau and boost the community economy”, was presented in Lisbon and Porto, at the beginning of October, by IPIM officials, who then also held presentations in neighboring Spain, in Madrid and Barcelona. IPIM promised to continue publicizing the plan, including through participation in convention and exhibition events, “encouraging cooperation between Macau companies and foreign brands, including those from Portuguese-speaking countries”.

item.title: Game | Seaport forecasts 19% revenue growth in January
item.description: The basis of comparison helps, but Macau's main industry continues to expand month after month. The most recent report from Seaport Research Partners predicts that revenues will increase by 14 percent annually by March Financial services firm Seaport Research Partners predicts 19 percent annual gaming revenue growth in January, according to the institution's most recent report. At a quarterly level, revenues can increase by around 14 percent. “Our estimate for January points to an increase of 19 percent compared to the previous year (4 percent more compared to the previous month), with the growth rate helped by an easy comparison [compared to the 2025 value]”, can be read in the report by analyst Vitaly Umansky, cited by the GGR Asia portal. In January 2025, the game's gross revenue was 18.3 billion patacas, the lowest value of the entire year, which contributes to the highest relative growth. Despite the low basis for comparison, the 19 percent growth in revenue at the beginning of the year is seen by Umansky as a “solid” sign for the first quarter, in which gaming revenue is expected to expand in the order of 14 percent. It is recalled that in the first three months of 2025, revenue reached 57.7 billion patacas. “We estimate that the month started very strong, possibly with revenues above 850 million patacas per day during the long weekend from January 1st to 4th”, the document states. Weakest December The forecast of 14 percent growth in the first quarter takes into account the fact that revenues slowed down in mid-December, which Seaport Research Partners believes is due to the fact that high rollers prefer to visit Macau to gamble between January and February. “We anticipate gross gaming revenues to grow more than 14 percent in the first quarter and seven percent in 2026,” Umansky said. “Growth in 2026 is supported by easy comparisons in the first half of the year and the continued easing of monetary flows and visa issuance”, he highlighted. Vitaly Umansky also said that if there is any unexpected increase in revenue in the mass market that the gaming industry's results could exceed the indicated forecast and that this increase would benefit concessionaires currently with greater capacity.

item.title: ZELENSKY VS ZELENSKY
item.description:
10/27/22 A Ukrainian pensioner, with the same name as the president, blames Zelensky for the prolongation of the conflict that destroyed his village. Zelensky, the villager, who never left his land, is now mortified because his favorite gravedigger died in the bomber. This Zelensky, a villager, represents half the world that recriminates the other Zelensky, the villain, for not wanting to negotiate with Putin. Negotiate what? The invader enters our house, covers his wife and daughter (cf. recent UN report on the rapes in Ukraine, in this “special operation”), an act that forced us to watch, and then we say to him: hi there, we are for peace, but we have to negotiate: you still haven't said what name you want to give the children! A peace that is not dignified is nothing more than a cessation of rights. As serious as the Russophobia that Putin inflicts on his people.
10/28/22 At a lunch with several guests, I heard a friend, who declared herself a spiritualist, explaining the particularities of her belief, in a calm and balanced way, I would even say, without a hint of “irrationalism”. He spoke at length and serenely, devoid of any fanatical proselytism. “Here is someone whose belief has brought thoughtfulness!” I thought, a rare alliance. However, at a certain moment a sentence comes out that horrifies me. It says, “there is no chance, nothing happens by chance!”, and I glimpse the voracious maws of holism. Because holism has a pathological aspect, like all good things, a shadow side. Two examples: in Hinduism there is less sensitivity to existential dramas, if that child suffers in this life this is just an expression of rigorous karmic symmetry, an effect of the acts he committed in his previous life. In Africa, it is not accepted that death could have been accidental, and many women are accused by the family of the deceased of having caused the death of their husband, in an act of manifest dementia, and, in the blatant majority of cases, a huge injustice for the wife — madness that spreads and infiltrates the social fabric. Buddhism introduced Compassion and Christianity introduced Caritas, trying to break with this logic, but in many other beliefs and religions the cage of causalities prevails over sensitivity to experience, the need to respond to the now. It is a tremendous logic that transforms the world into a Platonic stage, where we are nothing more than the shadows of something — an inextricable law -, in a determinism that calcifies all singularities, but that strangely fascinates many. The conquest of modernity was anchored in the conquest of chance and randomness, removing the incidences of a life from this fierce determinism that enclosed the world in a web. When the Renaissance freed the body from the influence of the stars, at that moment sexuality was relieved of guilt and individualism and its volition were able to emerge. There is an unequivocal moral implication in the phrase “there is no such thing as chance, nothing happens by chance!”, which should function as a key to self-knowledge and self-judgment, however, this phrase is usually used to seek a reason for things outside of us, in others. It's an alibi. Today there is a holistic temptation in the world, just as there was a satanic temptation in the Middle Ages, without much reflection on its consequences. Because it's not enough to want to connect everything in a resonant chain of affection. Even for the most unexpected: affection itself can kill. I realize, thanks to that cultured, balanced, intelligent woman, that “the fight” took place at the beginning of this century. One of the great mistakes of the 20th century was the false dichotomy between “rationalism and irrationalism”, a debate that extended to all fields, including art. First, rationality (the positive side of reason) was confused with rationalism (the pathological aspect of reason), and articulated in this lack of discernment, irrationalism was confused with freedom. Almost all 20th century art, with Surrealism at its head, made this mistake. The fallacy still exists despite the emergence of “irrationalism” and the consequent relativist currents that followed it having been consolidated everywhere. Essentially, much of what happened in the 20th century revolved around this clash between two paradigms: Rationalism versus Irationalism. Now, I see, we must save indeterminacy, chance, randomness from the terrible temptation of the cage of causalities. Holism, in its pathological form, may be reductionism that sets itself up as a new “eschatological narrative”. Is it “by chance” that holism emerges at a time when neo-liberalism and its cynical contempt for the human person is besieging everything, all freedoms, all acquired rights? Holistic awareness has brought a positive impact to greater ecological awareness, but followed with scholastic rigor, it stifles reality under the blanket of a determinism that is much more than uncomfortable: all great authoritarian ideologies are holistic. My friend will know how to combine her holistic and transpersonal belief with the freedom and responsibility that each moment asks of us — but how many will make the distinction, under a Law that explains and encompasses everything? How many will abandon themselves to what is? The awareness of the indeterminate brings tragic awareness, as the Greeks knew, but it also brings agency and the courage of decision. And we cannot give up on this. Furthermore, as Drummond shows in the poem “Quadrilha”, by Carlos Drummond de Andrade: «João loved Teresa who loved Raimundo/ who loved Maria who loved Joaquim who loved Lili/ who didn't love anyone./ João went to the United States, Teresa to the convent,/ Raimundo died of a disaster, Maria stayed with her aunt,/ Joaquim committed suicide and Lili married J. Pinto Fernandes/ who had not entered the story.» Real always runs outside the track, completely outside our concepts. That's what matters to us — a J. Pinto Fernandes emerges at the exact moment when we thought we had everything under control.

item.title: From Nobel and others
item.description: 9/10/22 When reading many people's reactions when this year's Nobel Prize for Literature was announced, I couldn't help but remember this comment from Jean-Pierre Siméon, in relation to another Nobel Prize: «An editor of a large national daily newspaper wrote five lines of indignation at the fact that the Nobel Prize for Literature had been awarded to Thomas Traströmer, a complete stranger. But unknown to whom? How did it not occur to this literary columnist, patented and paid to do his job, that his apparent ignorance was a matter of professional misconduct? Tranströmer had been translated into many languages, it was available in French.» There is always the chorus of those who wait for the Prize to be announced to complain about not having been invited to be on the jury, there is a subgroup of angry people who profess “I have never read it and I won’t even bother to read it”; It is a less than humble fauna, the one that inhabits social networks. I don't always know all the winners – I didn't know about the existence of Louise Glück, who I think is a great poet, or Olga Tokarczuk, for example – but this only brings me the comfort of knowing that the world is not a soap opera where everyone knows everyone else and the joy of recognizing that the yardstick of the world is not measured with my short measure and that, on the contrary, it gives me a new opportunity to face the unknown and learn from it. And perhaps the most stupid reaction was that of the intelligent man who wrote, But are there still people who read French?; simply confirming that today there is a new type of ignorance that is being raised with abandon: that of those who only read English. I would also prefer that, in French, Pascal Quignard, Linda Lê or even Sollers were awarded, or, among the new ones, Mathias Énard, but that does not detract from the dignity of Annie Ernaux's work (and it would have been enough to have written “Les Années”). There are books of hers that I like less, like the vulgar “Uma Paixão Simples”, but that happens with almost all authors, they have pivotal books and others that are like breaks in their itinerary. I recommend reading a beautiful book of interviews with her, “L’écriture comme un couteau”. 11/10/22 Yesterday an article appeared in the morning newspaper “Notícias”, in Maputo, reporting that the Pen Club Narrative Prize had been awarded to my wife, Teresa Noronha, for her soap opera “Tornado”, which had already won the Maria Velho da Costa Prize. The summary they made of the book does not even deserve comments, as it is pathetic, but what is important to highlight is the note of disqualification regarding its “Mozambicanness” when they call it Luso-Mozambican. It's not that it's inaccurate, but, for those who know the context, it's a touch naughty. Because finally, following the same logic, Adelino Timóteo should be called Tsonga-Mozambican, Álvaro Taruma Ronga-Mozambican, and Macua-Mozambican for writers from the north, etc., etc. Which doesn't appear to happen. At one point, in the novel, she writes: «Our color was never the dominant one. In colonial times we were not white, we were dressed in monhés, mugs of washed asses, the pejorative term to speak of a son of Goan and Portuguese. In the post-colonial period, I was not black and if, in Lisbon, they took me for Brazilian or Cape Verdean, in France they were lost in thought about where I was from and were surprised when they discovered that I was African. There I had to explain the wanderings of my DNA before settling in Mozambique. It took me a long time to accept that it was like that because yes, and that it was no curse that that was the case; on the contrary, I could even discover intense patterns of fantasy and freedom in this harlequin cloak that is our genealogy…” In modern-day Mozambique, it means being white… and that immediately takes precedence over what you do or what you are. It's sad, but as Naipaul warned, in these parts race is everything and people live as deeply immersed in it as, in other places, in religion. 12/10/22 Bruno Latour, an anthropologist who studied the sciences and their procedures and legitimations, law, technique and religions and who entertained himself by turning his back on the dogmas of the “moderns”, has died. For him, the place, the role of the specialist, was defined more by the perplexity he embodied than by the supposed truth that would sustain him. He proposed, as an alternative to the goodness of multiculturalism and its equivocal cliché “all different, all equal”, a return to “diplomacy”, given that this, precisely, does not start from the assumption that “we are unified because we share the same nature” but simply highlights that we “still do not share a common world”; It is necessary that we deal head-on with the “abyss of disagreement” that separates us, instead of trying to deceive it. And about politics he said, boldly: «If transparency is demanded from politicians, we kill them; if anyone demands fidelity to what the other was or what he says, kill him; If a mimetic relationship is required between what the crowd wants and what its representative says, representation is killed. These must therefore, by definition, betray, deceive, modify, distort the word. Without this ability to bend the word and betray, political language would not exist. I put forward the perfectly plausible hypothesis that political vocabulary will become as inaccessible as the religious language of the last twenty, three or fifty years.» (in “Un Monde Pluriel mais Commun”). I believe we will be needed to decipher this frantically complex world that has fallen to us.

item.title: Fuxi
item.description: O my friends, companions of these disastrous journeys through countries as old as the stars and the Moon, and as strange as the deepest interior of our wretched souls, what surprises still await us, what secret magics will we still have to overcome, what horrors will arise before our pupils dilated with astonishment and terror? Increasingly closer to our precarious existences, howls the monster of war, which threatens to merge humanity once and for all with the earth, incessantly traversed by the squalid specter of hunger and the invisible evil of ten thousand pestilences. Oh damned human, who believes you are superior to Nature itself, but then you reveal yourself, time and time again, incapable of simply ordering your existence and do not understand that you are possessed by fickle anger and are a slave to your own ambition! You are not satisfied with white jade or resplendent gold, there is no treasure that quenches your inextinguishable thirst for command over other men, animals and things; for eternal anguish dwells in you; in you the expelled serpents crawl; for you grows, powerful and impressive, the most fertile ivy of Evil! This is perhaps why on the Mount they call the White Deer, where one of the eight immortals on a sacred mount soared through the heavens towards Penglai, lives the fuxi, a bird whose shape resembles that of a rooster, although topped by a human head. What strange copulations, what monstrous embraces, what terrible procedures must have occurred to make the existence of this sinister animal possible? We don't know, but all it takes is for our exhausted mind to dare to come up with an answer, and then we feel our skin covered in horrendous goosebumps and our heart races in parade, like a wild horse whipped by the night whip of fear, unresponsive to reins and containment. Let men refrain from visiting Monte do Veado, because although there are riches capable of calming the wildest ambitions, if they have the unfortunate luck of catching a glimpse of a fuxi, it is certain that a war will soon break out and the cultivated fields will perish, because of it the tame animals will be beheaded, because of it the best young men of two generations will be sacrificed and the pride of the countries will be destroyed. The fuxi makes a sound reminiscent of its name. If you hear it, dark night or clear day, be on your way, because the path you are on is the surest path to misfortune!

item.title: Procrastinators Club
item.description: While rereading Easter, because of an article I'm preparing, I come across this excerpt, taken from “The Universal Man”: «Each man, morally, is one and absolute; but he has to live with attenuating his personality. (…) Coexistence is only possible between people reduced to a negative or hollow presence, which constantly gives way. Hence, the emptiness of society, an immense ghost made up of countless dead people. A superior man is antisocial or criminal. His destiny is prison and the desert». I hesitate to think whether Pascoaes reflects here on the political-social conditions that muzzle, and, worse, in a sad country like Portugal in the middle of the Estado Novo (and the book is from 1931) where any possibilities of spontaneity and frankness in human relationships were restricted, or if it merely lends to the behavior of (oppressed) men a metaphysical framework, an “essence”, declared in the presumption of each being, in isolation, “one and absolute”. Sometimes, in addition to an excess of Spirituality (or Saudade), Pascoaes lacks the world. He is a great poet, but he is a poet who takes Ampoules-of-Great-Ideas and who therefore writes often trapped by a programmatic furor, ceasing to have pores; It is not uncommon for a glass to be erected between him and reality, the same glass that made him write in O Bailado, from 1921: «Everything is a ghost. There are only clouds, clouds of voices, clouds of souls, of afflictions and tragedies! Clouds and more clouds, appearances and more appearances! And a divine lightning that pierces them, the instantaneous Apparition that appears and throws us to the ground, dazzled!» Sometimes I felt like reminding him, as António Sérgio did, in the article “Regeneration and Tradition, Moral and Economy”, which he dedicated to Pascoaes: «Pascoais, Pascoais my dear friend: you are a pure, excellent and noble poet, but also a victim of this social environment, like us all: of this horrible isolation that you praise and I curse». «As a child, he stole two blackbirds», says Jacinto do Prado Coelho, he stole them from a nest, and he felt remorse for that all his life. The Person, few more mischiefs are known to him. Only in Álvaro de Campos does a hint of wickedness and obscenity emerge: «Ah, and the ordinary and dirty people, who always look the same,/ Who use swear words as usual words,/ Whose sons steal from grocery store doors/ And whose daughters at the age of eight – and I think this is beautiful and I love it! –/ Decent-looking men masturbate in stairwells.” (Triumphal ode). Both poets, driven by a certain idea of ​​sanctity, had the same inability to break the siege of their skin with the overflow of someone else's dam, the same curse of sublimating the concrete ferocity of eros with the gentleness of the verses. Obviously, they are both “bigger than life”, but sometimes it makes me unnerved to watch, from my position as a hatter at the Procrastinators Club, the tantrums between them, just to see who occupies, in the internal organization, the position of President and Treasurer. Although Pessoa guessed more things, for example, what he wrote in the lesser-known Ode Martial and which is reflected in the situation we live in today, deferred, with his heart in his hands: «MARTIAL ODE (…) Helahoho! helahoho! The poor widow's sewing machine who was bayoneted... She sewed indefinitely in the afternoon… The table where the old people played, Everything mixed, everything mixed with bodies, with blood, All one river, one wave, one dragging horror. Helahoho! helahoho! I unearthed the child's tin train pressed into the middle of the [road, And I cried like all the mothers in the world about the horror of life. My pantheistic feet tripped over the sewing machine [widow who was killed with a bayonet And that poor instrument of peace stuck a spear in my heart. Yes, I was the one to blame for everything, I was the soldier for them all Who killed, raped, burned and broke, It was me and my shame and my remorse like a shadow [deformed They travel around the world like Ashavero, But behind my steps there are footsteps the size of infinity And a physical fear of being accountable to God makes me close my eyes. [eyes suddenly. (…) I ordered, captain, to shoot the trembling peasants, I let the daughters of all fathers tied to trees be raped, Now I saw that it was inside my heart that all this happened, And everything scalds and suffocates and I can't move without it [everything be the same. God have mercy on me, I didn't have it from anyone! LÀ-BAS, JE NE SAIS OÙ…” What is clear today, at this disastrous moment in which Cristiano & Companhia failed in their mission in Braga, and in which the self-sabotage of Russia's gas pipelines reminds us that Putin will indeed be willing to do anything to maintain dominance over the areas endorsed, is that, bomb for bomb, the “bomb” of the Fifth Empire was preferable. However, even in this, my dears, we were irresolute, a little more on the side of piella than determined, and we procrastinated.

item.title: Venezuela | Beijing will maintain support regardless of the political situation
item.description: The Chinese Government reaffirmed Friday that, regardless of what happens in Venezuela, the Asian country will continue to support Caracas in defending its sovereignty and national security. “China will continue to firmly support Venezuela in safeguarding its sovereignty, dignity and national security, regardless of how the political situation evolves,” said Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Mao Ning. The spokesperson highlighted that Beijing has maintained “solid” communication and cooperation with the Venezuelan Government and that the country “is deeply committed to deepening practical cooperation and promoting common development”. The Asian country, which has maintained close relations with Caracas in recent years, harshly condemned the United States' military intervention in Venezuela and demanded the release of former president Nicolás Maduro and his wife, Cilia Flores, who were taken to New York. The interim president of Venezuela, Delcy Rodríguez, met on Thursday with the Chinese ambassador, Lan Hu, highlighting China's “firm and consistent position in strongly condemning the serious violation of international law and Venezuelan sovereignty”, according to official Venezuelan information. North American sources cited by the ABC television network indicated that the Administration of the President of the United States, Donald Trump, informed Rodríguez that Venezuela will have to end its relations with China, Russia, Iran and Cuba as a condition for being able to extract and sell its oil.

item.title: Iran threatens to retaliate against US and Israel in case of attack
item.description: The president of Iran's parliament warned yesterday that the US military and Israel will be “legitimate targets” in the event of an attack by Washington, as threatened by US President Donald Trump. Mohammad Bagher Qalibaf's comments represent the first time that Israel has been included on the list of possible targets for an Iranian attack. Qalibaf, an Iranian hard-liner who has run for president in the past, made the threat as deputies stormed the parliament rostrum, shouting: “Death to America!” During the parliament session, broadcast live on Iranian state television, Mohammad Qalibaf gave a speech applauding the police and Iran's paramilitary Revolutionary Guard, particularly its Basij volunteers, for having “remained firm” during the protests held in the country against the Iranian theocracy. “The people of Iran must know that we will deal with them in the most severe manner and punish those who are detained,” he said. Qalibaf went on to directly threaten Israel, referring to it as “the occupied territory”, and also the US military: “In the event of an attack on Iran, both the occupied territory and all American military centers, bases and ships in the region will be our legitimate targets”, he stated, adding: “We do not consider ourselves limited to react after action and will act based on any objective signs of threat”. The seriousness of Iran's intentions regarding launching a potential attack is still unclear, especially after the country's air defenses were destroyed during June's 12-day war with Israel. Any decision to go to war would be up to Iran's supreme leader, 86-year-old 'Ayatollah' Ali Khamenei. Death on the street The US military has stated in the Middle East that it is “positioned with forces that span the full range of combat capabilities to defend itself, partners and allies, and US interests.” Meanwhile, the protests that have been taking place in Iran for two weeks, challenging the regime and which, according to the Human Rights Activists News Agency (HDRANA), have already caused at least 192 deaths, led protesters yesterday to flood the streets of the capital and the country's second largest city. The New York Times and Wall Street Journal, citing unnamed US officials, said Saturday night that Trump had been given military options for an attack on Iran but had not made a final decision.

item.title: Japan leader considers dissolving parliament and calling elections, press reveals
item.description: Japan's Prime Minister, Sanae Takaichi, is considering dissolving parliament and calling early elections in January, according to the Japanese press. According to the Japanese news agency Kyodo, which cites sources close to the discussions, the dissolution could occur at the beginning of the ordinary session of the Diet (the Japanese parliament), which begins on January 23. If parliament is dissolved, the campaign for the general elections could begin on January 27th or February 3rd, with voting scheduled for February 8th or 15th, depending on when the campaign begins. According to the Japanese newspaper Yomiuri Shimbun, which cites the same dates, Takaichi is considering dissolving the Diet due to the high approval ratings that the Government has enjoyed since taking power in October, following the dismissal of his predecessor, Shigeru Ishiba, as head of the Government and leader of the ruling party in Japan. Due to a series of unfavorable election results, Takaichi's Liberal Democratic Party and coalition partners hold a slim one-seat majority in the House of Representatives (the more important of the Diet's two chambers) and are in the minority in the House of Councilors. To date, Takaichi has consistently rejected the possibility of calling early elections, instead stressing the importance of passing measures to address the impact on households of persistent inflation and stagnant wages. Regional tension The Prime Minister's Government has high approval ratings despite worsening tensions between Tokyo and Beijing. On Wednesday, China announced a ban on the export of dual-use products to Japan, a measure that could include certain rare earth elements, essential for the manufacture of high-technology components. This is after, in November, the Prime Minister admitted, in the Japanese parliament, a possible military response by Japan to a Chinese attack against Taiwan. Sanae Takaichi stated that if an emergency situation in Taiwan involved “the deployment of warships and the use of force, this could constitute a threat to Japan’s survival.”

item.title: Taiwan | Ethiopia and reaffirms support for the ‘One China’ principle
item.description: The Ethiopian Government on Friday rejected “any form of Taiwan independence” and reaffirmed its support for the “one China” principle, considering the island a province of Chinese territory. The position was expressed in a joint statement after a meeting in Addis Ababa between Ethiopia's Foreign Minister, Gedion Timothewos, and his Chinese counterpart, Wang Yi, who is visiting the African continent. “Ethiopia reaffirms its firm commitment to the principle of ‘one China’ and declares that there is only one China in the world, that Taiwan is an inalienable part of Chinese territory and that the Government of the People's Republic of China is the only legal Government that represents all of China”, reads the official note. Both parties also stressed that “all countries must respect the principles established in the United Nations Charter and international law, respect the sovereignty and territorial integrity of States and oppose the use or threat of the use of force in international relations”.

item.title: BRICS+ | Ships from China, Russia, Iran and South Africa in military exercise
item.description: Since Friday, the naval fleet with ships from BRICS countries has participated in the “Will for Peace 2026” operation in South African territory Ships from China, Russia and Iran joined host South Africa where they began a military exercise on Friday, in which other countries from the BRICS+ group also participate, raising geopolitical tensions with the United States. According to the South African army, this operation, called “Will for Peace 2026” and led by China, aims to “guarantee the safety of maritime transport” and “deepen cooperation” between the bloc’s members, with the exercises expected to run until January 16th. The naval fleet, which has Chinese, Russian and Iranian ships, includes the Chinese destroyer Tangshan, 161 meters long, with ships expected to be sent by the United Arab Emirates (UAE), while countries such as Brazil, Indonesia and Ethiopia participate as observers. A spokesperson for the South African armed forces said it was not possible to confirm all participating countries, such as India, Egypt and Saudi Arabia, in the exercises. The South African Ministry of Defense stressed that this naval exercise “has nothing to do with Venezuela”, ruling out any connection with the seizures of ships off the Latin American country, which Washington began in December, before removing the Venezuelan head of state, Nicolas Maduro. “This exercise had been in preparation since 2025 and was postponed due to the G20 summit that took place in the same period” in Johannesburg, South Africa, he added. An attempt at appeasement had no effect on the United States, which boycotted this first summit of the group of 20 most developed countries held in Africa. Donald doesn't like it The bloc of emerging countries that are the Brics+ was accused by the North American President, Donald Trump, of carrying out “anti-American” policies. In February, Trump stated, in a decree, that South Africa supports “bad actors on the world stage” and highlighted its relations with Iran as one of the reasons for the US to cut funding to the country. According to Pretoria Institute of Security Studies researcher Priyal Singh, “Washington has had Pretoria in its sights since the start of the current Trump administration” and “the image conveyed by the upcoming naval exercises will likely be used by policymakers in Washington as a perfect example to show why bilateral relations with South Africa should be reviewed.” South Africa has long claimed to follow a non-aligned foreign policy and remain neutral, but the Russian presence in the southern tip of the African continent has strained its relations with the US before. These naval exercises are expected to add further tension to relations between the US and South Africa, which is Africa's most advanced economy and a leading voice on the continent. The complexity of the event is further reinforced by the participation of the Iranian navy in a period of growing internal instability and protests against the leadership of the Islamic Republic in the country. Members of the BRICS group are long-time members Brazil, China, Russia, India and South Africa, while Iran, Egypt, Ethiopia and the United Arab Emirates joined the group in 2024.

item.title: Diplomacy | Official visit to Somalia postponed
item.description: China's Foreign Minister has postponed his visit to Somalia scheduled for Friday, as part of his tour of Africa, the Somali presidency announced. "We regret that the planned visit of the Chinese Foreign Minister has been postponed at the last minute. We apologize", sources from the Somali presidency told the Spanish agency EFE, without giving a justification for the postponement, nor indicating a new date for the official visit. Wang Yi's trip would be the first by a head of Chinese diplomacy to this country in the Horn of Africa since the 1980s. The cancellation occurred at a time when the Somali capital, Mogadishu, was practically paralyzed due to a strong security arrangement throughout the city, set up to receive the head of Chinese diplomacy. The postponement comes at a time when the Somali government is seeking international support, after Israel recognized, in December, the secessionist Somali region of Somaliland as an independent state, becoming the first country to take this step. This decision provoked broad international rejection, especially in Africa, the Islamic world, China and the European Union. Somalia has been in a situation of conflict and chaos since the fall of Mohamed Siad Barre in 1991, which left the country without an effective government and in the hands of Islamist militias, such as Al-Shebab, and warlords.

item.title: Japan | Member of nuclear regulator loses cell phone in China
item.description: Japanese authorities are investigating the loss of a professional cell phone, allegedly in China, which contained a confidential list of contacts from the Nuclear Regulation Authority, as confirmed to France-Presse by a person responsible for the organization. The incident, now made public, occurred at Shanghai airport, on November 3, when the employee was going through security control. The absence of the device was only noticed three days later, and, according to the Japanese press, it was not possible to block it or remotely erase its data as it was already out of reach. Although the cell phone did not contain direct access to nuclear data, according to the person in charge – who did not want to be identified – the list included names and contact details of members of the regulatory authority's nuclear safety division – information that is not publicly accessible due to the sensitivity of the functions. The revelation comes in a context of growing tension between Beijing and Tokyo, after Japanese Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi suggested in November that the country could intervene militarily in the event of Chinese aggression against Taiwan. At the same time, the operator Tokyo Electric Power (TEPCO) is seeking final approval to reactivate the Kashiwazaki-Kariwa nuclear plant, the largest in the world, closed after the Fukushima disaster in 2011. Japan has been gradually resuming nuclear energy, with 14 reactors already reactivated, within the framework of carbon neutrality targets by 2050 and increased demand for electricity due to artificial intelligence. The lost cellphone was reported to Japanese data protection authorities in November, according to the nuclear regulator. The case reignites concerns about information security in the nuclear energy sector at a delicate moment in Japanese energy policy.

item.title: Hong Kong | Zhipu AI leads round of stock market debuts worth 1,030 ME
item.description: Investor interest in the technology market continues to bear fruit and leads more and more Chinese companies linked to Artificial Intelligence to enter the Hong Kong stock exchange The Chinese artificial intelligence company Zhipu AI debuted on the Hong Kong stock exchange yesterday, on a day when two other technology companies also entered the market, collectively raising 1.2 billion dollars. Zhipu, officially called Knowledge Atlas Technology and which adopts the name Z.ai in foreign markets, registered an upward trend in the middle of the session, with a value of 11.19 percent, after having raised around 559 million dollars. It is the first Chinese company specializing exclusively in large-scale language models to be listed on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange. According to its co-founder and executive director, Zhang Peng, the choice of this financial center is related to the company's internationalization ambitions. Zhang said that Hong Kong and Southeast Asia will be the first markets to be explored, followed by the Middle East, Europe and the so-called “Global South”. The manager pointed to low costs as Zhipu's main attraction compared to competing models, with the aim of winning over new users. The technology company thus joins other Chinese companies in the sector that have taken advantage of investors' interest in the growth of AI in the country. One of Zhipu's main competitors, MiniMax – also a rival to OpenAI (creator of ChatGPT) and Anthropic (developer of Claude) – is scheduled to debut on the same exchange on Friday. Other premieres Yesterday, graphics chip maker Shanghai Iluvatar CoreX Semiconductor, which opened with gains of 31.5 percent after raising US$473 million, and surgical robot producer Edge Medical, which rose 36.4 percent, raising around US$154 million, also debuted in Hong Kong. Last week, Biren Technology, which specializes in AI chips, rose nearly 76 percent on its first day of trading. In December, two other companies in the sector, Moore Threads and MetaX, recorded increases of more than 100 percent on the Shanghai stock exchange. Despite admitting that Chinese models are closing the gap compared to North Americans, Zhang Peng acknowledged that gaps still persist in areas such as research, resources and innovation. Zhipu was placed on a commercial blacklist by the United States in 2025, making it difficult for it to access North American technology.

item.title: Cambodia liquidates bank of tycoon leader of fraud network
item.description: Cambodia announced yesterday the immediate liquidation of Prince Bank, owned by Chinese tycoon Chen Zhi, detained this week and extradited to China, where he is being investigated for leading a transnational fraud and human trafficking network. In a resolution published by the National Bank of Cambodia, the entity was prevented from accepting deposits and granting loans, one day after Phnom Penh confirmed Chen's arrest and handover to Beijing. The settlement will be supervised by the company Morisonkak MKA, which will guarantee the withdrawal of deposits by customers and the continuation of payment of ongoing credits. Prince Bank was one of more than 100 companies in the Prince Group conglomerate, founded by Chen Zhi, which over the past decade has expanded into areas such as tourism, technology, logistics, food and finance. Several of these companies have been identified by Washington as fronts for online fraud schemes and human trafficking networks in Southeast Asia. The Cambodian Interior Ministry said Chen, 37, was detained on Tuesday “as part of cooperation to combat transnational crime and at the request of Chinese authorities.” The operation also included the capture of Chinese citizens Xu Ji Liang and Shao Ji Hui, who were also extradited. Joint investigation Phnom Penh revealed that Chen was stripped of Cambodian nationality in December, by royal decree, months after ensuring that the businessman had obtained it legally. The arrest, according to the statement, was the result of “months of joint investigation” with China. Last October, the US Department of Justice charged Chen with financial crimes linked to forced labor. US authorities allege that the businessman led an “industrial-scale” online fraud operation, involving hundreds of victims held under duress in prison-like facilities in Cambodia. US courts confiscated $15 billion in bitcoin from the group, in the largest seizure of cryptocurrencies in its history. Last year, Cambodia's interior ministry spokesman stated that Chen was not in the country and that neither he nor his company faced local charges. The change in position has now been interpreted as a sign of greater alignment with Beijing in combating financial crime and cross-border fraud networks.

item.title: Sofia Ferreira da Silva, author of a study on opera in the Mao years: “Silk Road was the biggest influence”
item.description: In “Singing the Revolution: The Role of Songs and Opera in the Spread of Communism in Mao Zedong's China”, Sofia Ferreira da Silva analyzes the way in which songs and opera spread political ideals, leaving marks on the country's cultural panorama. The analysis came from the doctoral thesis in Artistic Studies, defended by the author at Universidade Nova de Lisboa What was the musical environment like in the country before Mao Zedong came to power? China was, and continues to be, a territory with a huge variety of practices at regional, local and ethnic levels. We can speak of four main types: music of a more erudite nature, symbolized by court music (yayue) and guqin music, more centered on Confucian ideals and with ritual functions and self-cultivation of individual morality; folk music, with vocal and instrumental genres varying according to region and ethnicity; Taoist, Buddhist and other religious music; and traditional opera, such as Kunqu and Peking, Sichuan and Canton operas, combining singing, declamation, stylized movements and martial arts. The biggest influence on Chinese music was, perhaps, the Silk Road, as a good part of the musical instruments that are now considered “Chinese”, such as the erhu, the pipa, the suona and the sanxian, have their origins in foreign instruments brought to Chinese territory, and which were gradually adapted and incorporated into their music. On the other hand, some narrative and operatic genres evolved from the adaptation and combination of counterparts from the territories crossed by this route. If it weren't for the Silk Road, traditional Chinese music would be radically different. What other influences are there? The other big influence is Western music. This, despite having entered the country in the 16th and 17th centuries, was felt with greater intensity from the middle of the 19th century and throughout the 20th century. The growing foreign presence and influence led to the systematic introduction of Western notation, academic training along European lines and Western classical and popular music genres, which would be assimilated in varying ways by Chinese composers, such as Ma Sicong, Li Jinhui or Xian Xinghai, combining them or not with traditional music motifs. In the thesis, he talks about two major changes in the Mao years, with the creation of the so-called “model shows (yangbanxi)” and the revolutionary Peking operas. How did these formats help to reshape the music scene at the time? The model shows, which include Peking operas and revolutionary songs, played an important role in reforming the Maoist musical landscape, implying changes not only in musical styles, but also in the social function of music. Production became entirely subordinated to the political project of the Chinese Communist Party (PCC), resulting in the mandatory membership of artists and designated artistic associations, and the suppression, through criticism in the media, of musical elements or genres considered “feudal”, “bourgeois” or “superstitious”. In opposition, and following successive political movements and campaigns, other formats were promoted, more in line with the regime's ideals. How, in concrete terms? In the case of the “yangbanxi”, from the Cultural Revolution, the fact that they were called “model” implied that all new creations must strictly follow the aesthetic precepts established through them, especially the rules of the “basic task”, with the construction of revolutionary heroic figures as the ultimate aim of artistic creation. There were also the “Three Prominences”, with the attribution of greater or lesser prominence to a certain character depending on their degree of positivity or negativity, their function in the plot. These rules guided not only the narrative structure and the role of the characters, but also aspects such as the integration between music and gestures, the construction of costumes and sets, and the harmony between traditional and Western musical elements. This codification would aim, to this extent, to guarantee the ideological and aesthetic uniformity essential to the creation of a controlled, functional and politically effective musical culture within the framework of the objectives of the revolution. What are the main political messages conveyed through these two types of shows? The first big idea is the almost religious loyalty to Mao Zedong and the unconditional observance of his ideas. It is his thought that inspires and guides the actions of the heroes and heroic characters, the second most important category of characters in revolutionary operas, and leads them to the successful completion of the mission assigned to them or to heroic sacrifice in favor of the communist cause. The second is the class struggle as the driving force of history. We have, on the one hand, the oppressive, capitalist, imperialist and feudal class as the villain, and on the other the working people, exploited and oppressed by the former, suffering the greatest storms at their hands. The conflicts and difficult situations faced by the heroes or other positive characters, such as the death of family members, imprisonment or slavery, were always the direct expression of this struggle, and their resolution would only come from the revolutionary stance and the assumption of an active role in the construction of socialism. And the third idea present in the shows? This is collectivism, as a true revolutionary places the interests of the Party and the People above any individual dream or desire. No matter how prominent his role, the hero needs popular support to complete his mission: his aspirations are the aspirations of the people, and it is in solidarity between all that difficulties are overcome and the much-desired socialist harmony is achieved. Personal achievement only has value if it serves the collective cause, and individual sacrifice is glorified when it contributes to common progress. Operas promote, to this extent, a worldview where individual identity dissolves into the identity of the revolutionary collective, and where the active participation of the masses is not only desirable, but necessary. These were years of so-called cultural Maoism, as mentioned in the thesis. How is it characterized? Cultural Maoism presents points of contact regarding the subordination of art to politics, the valorization of the daily lives of the masses as the raw material for creation and the defense of its widespread popularization. However, it is distinguished by its emphasis on the proletarianization of the artist himself, who should abandon his position as a distant intellectual and become an active member of the working people, learning through practice and inserting himself in their daily struggles. What are the main influences of this movement? In addition to the Marxist-Leninist matrix, cultural Maoism would be marked by Confucian influences, giving art an ethical and formative function, as in Confucius, Mencius or Xunzi, art shaped character. However, in the Maoist context, this molding was channeled towards the construction of socialist consciousness and the eradication of traces of the bourgeois mentality. One of the central principles of this policy was the “mass line”, a kind of circular cultural dynamic in which popular ideas and expressions were collected and systematized by the Party, before being returned to the people in a clearer and more politically oriented way. Another aspect to consider is the appreciation of native and foreign cultural heritage, condensed in the maxim “use the past to serve the present, use the foreign to serve China”. In what way? To create new artistic works, Mao recommended the initial study of Western works, considered “scientific” and technically superior, before selectively incorporating elements of Chinese tradition. In both cases, the value of artistic forms lay in their social and political function, not in their preservation as heritage. In this context, the PCC leader proposed two criteria for artistic evaluation: the political, which required the promotion of national unity and the rejection of ideas contrary to the Party; and the artistic, which presupposed technical and aesthetic rigor following an abstract notion of “scientific criteria of art” at the service of the masses. This double requirement replaced, in Maoism, the Confucian distinction between moral quality and aesthetic quality. In these years, what were the biggest influences on songwriting? The composition of songs was greatly influenced by two great musical traditions: the native, with the use of regional melodies and motifs and those of the various ethnic minorities that make up the territory; and the Western, in which I include the Soviet musical tradition, most visible in marches and so-called “art songs”, which could be understood as a type of revolutionary ‘lieder’ or with highly politicized content. The influence of each of them was more or less visible depending on the political situation of the territory. How did the years of “cultural Maoism” change the country’s musical landscape? Some aspects of the production of Cultural Revolution operas, such as the introduction of the Western orchestra and the use of techniques from Western music, the incorporation of more realistic scenarios and the melodramatic nature of the stories influenced and continue to influence the production of new Beijing operas, especially those with contemporary or historical themes relating to the 20th century. XX. Over the last 30 years, operas with historical themes have also been produced with some of these elements, especially in terms of music and settings, such as “Cao Cao and Yang Xiu”. Some remnants of this period can also be seen in the interpretation of traditional operas, especially in the presentation of arias or excerpts on television programs. I see countless performances that combine, just like in the revolutionary repertoire, arrangements with a Western orchestra and realistic scenarios, with extensive use of new technologies. However, what I consider to be the greatest remnant of revolutionary operas will, perhaps, be a greater artistic audacity on the part of the creators of new operas. It is an issue that deserves further study by the academy, but, from my observations as a spectator, I notice a greater openness to the incorporation of elements from other arts, such as dance and theater, and a greater complexity in the characters, especially those considered negative, less antagonistic, with more nuances when it comes to motivations for acting in a certain way. It is obvious that the psychological suffering inflicted by these operas on an entire generation of Chinese people is undeniable and cannot, under any circumstances, be forgotten; however, model operas boosted the creative impetus of composers and librettists, in line with the evolutionary process, of fusion with other arts, of Peking Opera over the centuries.

item.title: Alfredo Gomes Dias, historian, on Rocha Vieira: “A historical figure, whether he wanted to or not”
item.description: Launched on Thursday in Porto, with the seal of War and Peace, “Macau: The Last Transition – Vasco Rocha Vieira (1991–1999)” is the result of 20 years of work by historian Alfredo Gomes Dias. The work contains personal testimonies from Rocha Vieira and documented details of the last Portuguese Administration of Macau Another book has just been released about Rocha Vieira and the last Portuguese administration of Macau. Tell me about the beginning of this project. This project is more or less 20 years old, and began when I met Rocha Vieira, in 2005, to write a text for the book “Governadores de Macau” [published by Livros do Oriente in 2013]. In the midst of this, I discovered that there was a personal document fund of General Rocha Vieira, while governor. As a historian, I was excited by the idea. I offered to do a project with him, which we called a “report”. All the documents were at his home, in Lagoa, where he was from. They were then deposited in a space provided by Mafra City Council and between 2007 and 2013 I worked on this documentation. It was lonely and long work, because I had to organize 1,700 boxes of documentation and combine it with my work as a teacher. Rocha Vieira kept postponing the project, saying no, but in 2016 he told me to move forward with the “report”, the book. I finished the first version in 2021. It is a committed book, in the sense that it aims to give General Rocha Vieira's vision of what his Government was like. This is not an academic work. He had complete access to the personal file. He gave me the green light to consult all the documentation, I had no restrictions. Rocha Vieira told me one story or another in detail, gave me guidelines and revealed to me his concerns during his government. He told me some positions he had and then the different paths they took, and the entire book is built around the many conversations I had with the general, in which I also use documentation. We have a vision of everything that happened between 1991 and 1999 and the governor's actions in the different dimensions of the Administration, at an economic, social and political level, in relations with China and Lisbon, with Hong Kong, and then everything related to the work related to the transformation of the territory, such as the birth of Cotai and the major works that were carried out. There is also talk about the transition phase and the major themes, such as the entry of Chinese troops into Macau, the ceremony and how it was organized. Today we live in an immediate world, and at today's speed it's always strange to say that this book took 20 years to make. Can we say that this is the first time that we have such a complete testimony of Rocha Vieira's vision of his Government? The edited biography [Vasco Rocha Vieira – Todos os Portos a que Aguei] already gives many ideas about his concerns. What I ended up doing was not focusing so much on the general's entire life, but only on the years of the Government and developing as much as possible many of the issues that Pedro Vieira raised in this biography. What subjects are then further developed in this new work? I describe very well all the processes linked to Macau's transition, such as the issue of laws and localization, the need to translate them into Chinese. This was a gigantic job. Then I discuss the construction of major works, the birth of Cotai. All of this based on the original plans and plans designed for Cotai, where the beginning of the idea for this area is known. Any historian who, in the future, wants to study the transition process must necessarily go through this book. I don't want to say that what's there is definitive, because it never is. But it is important to have this basis and testimony, which is enriched and substantiated by documentation. I imagine that the controversies of the Rocha Vieira Government are also in the book. The quarrel with Jorge Sampaio, the creation of the Fundação Oriente in Portugal. What is Rocha Vieira’s testimony about these two moments? He always maintained the same speech compared to what he had already said publicly. There is a specific chapter on Fundação Oriente, where, with the support of documentation, an attempt is made to explain the process and why Rocha Vieira, when he arrived in Macau, felt the need to solve a problem that had been dragging on and which was important to overcome. It describes how he managed to resolve it, as it was an issue that was making dialogue with the Chinese authorities difficult. It explains how Rocha Vieira interacted with the different Governments of the [Portuguese] Republic and the different Presidents, the positions he took in order to guarantee what was his responsibility. While he was at the head of the Government, Rocha Vieira always tried to assert his views, and one of the interesting things is that I had access to copies of minutes of meetings of the State Council, in which Rocha Vieira presented his vision on the situation in Macau. It's an interesting contribution. But he explains that the way he spoke with President Mário Soares was completely different from the way he spoke with Jorge Sampaio. The institutional relationship changed, the way of attending a meeting was also different. This is explained, but without going into the personal side of the dispute. Did Rocha Vieira leave Macau with a feeling of accomplishment? I think he left Macau very convinced, and the entire transfer ceremony ends up giving us this image that Portugal left in the best possible way. We also have to think that we are talking about two completely different countries, and that one of them is giant. And that, despite this difference, it was possible to maintain an almost equal dialogue between two States to resolve, in the best way, a specific issue that was Macau. What surprised me most about Rocha Vieira's vision was that he changed the centrality of his vision to Macau. In what sense? In general, the Portuguese and the authorities spoke of Macau thinking about guaranteeing the transition process without jeopardizing Portugal's interests. And General Rocha Vieira reverses the terms of the issue, that is, to guarantee Macau's interests, with the idea that guaranteeing Macau's interests would be the same as guaranteeing Portugal's interests. It looks like the same thing, but it's not. This vision, for me, was surprising. Why? Because it went against what was the most common discourse among the authorities and people responsible for the Portuguese administration [of Macau]. This central idea ends up changing the way he organizes his Government, how he acts and the type of actions he triggers. They all had to do with this deep conviction, that, in the remaining years, a great development of Macau would be guaranteed, the affirmation of Portuguese culture, supporting institutions, or even with the Portuguese School of Macau (EPM), whose solution ended up not being the one he proposed. It turned out to be a minimalist option. What, specifically, was Rocha Vieira’s position? It was to ensure that the old Macau High School was the EPM, which would give the school a completely different dimension compared to [the current location]. It has nothing to do with it. He didn't just want a Portuguese school, but also a space where it was possible to develop cultural activities, create a cultural hub in Macau linked to Portugal, and with a much more dignified option than what was, later, the option of the Ministry of Education, in the figure of Marçal Grilo, who chose [the location] of the old Commercial School. Therefore, the focus has always been to guarantee and develop Macau's interests, its autonomy, and the airport issue was fundamental to guarantee Macau's autonomy. It was also intended that Macau would adhere to international agreements regarding respect for human rights. The idea was that, by managing to guarantee Macau's interests, thinking of the territory as part of China's second system, and that if we invested a lot in Macau, we would, naturally, be defending Portuguese interests and leaving a great legacy. What was the most complex dossier for Rocha Vieira? I think he had great regrets about the Ministry of Education's option for Portuguese schools. From the conversations I had with him [that's what it seemed to me]. Then there were the security issues, with the sects, which ended up being resolved. The years 1997 and 1998 were very critical moments in Macau, but as it always had good relations with the Chinese authorities, this led to China realizing the situation, starting to collaborate more with the Portuguese authorities in Macau, in order to control the problem. About Cotai, how did the idea come about? It arises in the context of the airport works, when it is realized that it would be relatively easy to mobilize the land that was associated with the airport works, taking advantage of that moment to make a connection and create, essentially, a second urban center in Macau. Cotai's initial plans had to do with urban space, green and industrial spaces. The entire plan was designed to bring together different areas, social spaces, such as schools or health, as if Cotai were a mini-city, so to speak, in the territory. But who actually had the idea? It was an idea from Rocha Vieira's Executive, developed with secretaries. The idea came from him, when he was faced with the issue of the works, and was then developed with the team. He was always concerned about developing things with the team, also ensuring continuity with what had been done before. When he talked to me, he was careful to say: “this didn't start with me”, or that this or that secretary had been fundamental for a certain job. He never wanted to take credit that wasn't his, and this is also a great recognition from previous governors. Therefore, Cotai was not supposed to have so much area dedicated to the game. From what I analyzed in the documents, there was no idea of ​​giving up such a large space for entertainment, with casinos. I think the initial vision for Cotai was a little more balanced, with housing, schools, health centers, green spaces. It was supposed to be a new urban space that would be created with all the services necessary to function, it wasn't just supposed to be games. The moments in which Rocha Vieira clutches the flag to his chest, moved, will go down in history. Did he remember those moments with you? Yes, but despite the historical dimension of his role, Rocha Vieira was not exactly aware of the historical role he was playing. He was there with a clear mission and objectives, without really thinking about the role he could have in the future. Once, when we were having lunch, I told him that we could put our work into perspective, but that he was going to become a historical figure in the history of Portugal, whether he wanted to or not. And the funny thing is that he looked at me with a face like he had never thought of that, with a very surprised look. In fact, it is unthinkable to take away his status as the last Portuguese governor in Macau in hundreds of years of history. On top of that, he was there for a long period [9 years], when most governors were there for three or four years.

item.title: Christian Montag, UM Institute for Collaborative Innovation: “AI cannot imitate the human touch”
item.description: Can artificial intelligence help combat loneliness? The issue was analyzed in a study by the University of Macau, led by academic Christian Montag. The director of the Institute for Collaborative Innovation emphasizes that AI tools “are not long-term solutions” on a psychological level How can artificial intelligence (AI) help overcome feelings of loneliness, if social networks cannot achieve this goal? The “needs and gratifications theory” states that technology can only be successful if its use satisfies human needs, such as, for example, the need for social interaction. With AI companions, whether as stand-alone products or integrated into social media platforms, we have reached a new level, because human beings start talking to an artificial person and not with another human person, as happens on social media. Specific problems arise with these new AI companions, in that there are overly pleasant and charming AI systems that do not challenge a person's biased views of the world. Furthermore, many people around the world have become overly dependent on these products, using them without critical reflection. One of the conclusions of your study is that AI cannot, on its own, resolve feelings of loneliness. What steps in the investigation were followed to reach this conclusion? There are well-conducted studies that show that interactions with AI companions can actually reduce feelings of loneliness. We do not doubt these results nor deny the potential that can arise from these interactions between humans and AI, as long as such systems are designed safely and when a human is not available. That said, we believe that these interactions between humans and AI do not represent a long-term solution. Why? This is due to the absence of social contact and the real presence of another human being when turning to AI companions based on large-scale language models, especially in moments of desperation. We have reviewed a vast literature that demonstrates that we need to take our evolutionary heritage seriously, with the real need for other human beings, particularly in the age of AI. Our perspective is based on many years of research in the area of ​​affective neuroscience. Still, it is clearly necessary to develop more new empirical studies that directly address interactions with AI and support this vision. We run the risk of AI causing profound cognitive changes in people. To what extent? Can we change as human beings, especially when it comes to our need for others? The same discussion arose with the appearance of smartphones. It is important to note that this oldest discussion has not yet been resolved: what happens or happened to our cognitive abilities when we began to permanently outsource the learning of telephone numbers, the guidance from A to B, among other tasks, to a machine? Recent research from MIT [Massachusetts Institute of Technology] suggests that the brain is less activated when using ChatGPT for writing tasks, compared to writing without such support. To me, this is not surprising and should not lead to moral panics. We have other more urgent problems, such as when real difficulties arise when inequalities in society increase, this is because some people use AI and others do not invest in this area. What are the concrete impacts? Some people may soon become very, very productive, while those who are not educated to use AI properly will not be able to keep up. Interestingly, we have observed in recent research that people with a deep learning style are more willing to engage with AI to become more productive. As for the question of whether we have changed in relation to our need for others, I highly doubt that, as these evolutionary impulses are genetically anchored in our species and we cannot simply eliminate them. Social needs are an essential part of what it means to be human. Could these cognitive changes, if they occur, be more significant in young people than in adults, for example? Interesting question. We know, from some studies on attitudes towards AI, that younger users tend to have more positive views about AI and, therefore, are more likely to adopt it in their daily lives. However, we are currently observing something quite problematic, such as the fact that AI is often eliminating jobs for young people just leaving university. Thus, AI appears to make it more difficult to enter the job market after obtaining a university degree. In other words, a lack of work experience makes things difficult for many young people. In the end, this could also lead to young people's perception of AI becoming more negative soon. How should governments legislate or adopt policies to promote healthy acceptance and use of AI in society and schools? We see very different approaches around the world to respond to the AI ​​revolution. I am German and, in Europe, we are seeing strong regulatory efforts with the so-called Artificial Intelligence Regulation (Artificial Intelligence Act). Personally, I am not convinced that the current European regulatory scheme is well planned, as I think it is too strict and, in some points, uses legally undefined terms, although I applaud the aim of promoting reliable AI and trying to reduce harm. I think the current regulation of AI in the European Union could go too far and end up harming the European economy by stifling much-needed innovation. But there are real dangers associated with AI and some regulation is needed. What dangers? I'm talking, for example, about the unregulated fusion between biotechnology and AI that could result in harm if people start to “create” new viruses in their backyards. I find Singapore's approach based on lifelong learning as a response to the AI ​​revolution very interesting. The Singapore Government offers its citizens the possibility of obtaining an academic degree in AI from the age of 40, with financial support from the State itself. What I like about this approach is that we need to remind people that it is also their responsibility to acquire new skills throughout their lives. This mentality must be instilled from an early age in schools. In what areas of our lives can large-scale language models (LLMs) do more good than harm? There are many routine and repetitive tasks where AI will be really useful to humans. However, we know from scientific literature that humans experience what is called “algorithm aversion”: in some areas of our lives, people do not like AI playing a role. For example, when we talk about couples therapy, people clearly prefer to talk to a human being than an AI system. Perhaps the closer we come to our evolutionary heritage in terms of caring for each other, the more the role of AI must be carefully monitored and reflected upon if we want it to have a place there. Personally, I wouldn't want to see my child being taken care of in kindergarten by an AI-powered robot. How should psychology adapt to AI, given the growing number of people using it for this purpose? There are different perspectives on this topic. Firstly, not everyone knows that psychology is a discipline that relies heavily on data. Therefore, psychology students are trained to become excellent data scientists. In this context, it is logical that our discipline adopts AI as a data analysis tool. However, I think it speaks to how psychologists view the increasing use of AI in human relationships. As with many things, this is complex. If AI enables better human communication, such as improving hearing aids for people with hearing problems, that is very welcome. If AI replaces human relationships, from my perspective it will cause problems. As we exposed in our most recent work, AI cannot currently successfully imitate human social touch or the real presence of another person. At the Center for Cognitive and Brain Science at the University of Macau, what are the main projects developed in this area? We have unique research opportunities at the University of Macau to study interactions between humans and AI, using neuroscientific techniques. I hope we can publish very interesting discoveries in the near future. Humanity still lives here Recently published in the scientific journal “Trends and Cognitive Sciences”, the article “Can AI really help solve the loneliness epidemic?” [Can AI Really Help Solve the Loneliness Epidemic?] counts Christian Montag, associate director of the Institute for Collaborative Innovation at the University of Macau (UM) as lead author, followed by academics Michiel Spapé, associate professor at the Center for Cognitive and Brain Sciences at UM, and Benjamin Becker, professor at the Department of Psychology at the University of Hong Kong, as co-authors. According to a press release released by UM regarding this investigation, one of the main conclusions is that AI “will probably not be a long-term solution to human loneliness”. Quoted in this note, Christian Montag stated that “if a person is lonely, they long for the physical presence of someone close to them”, and this “is very difficult to imitate with the available chatbots”. "The major language models operate primarily through text communication. Clearly, this is not enough to provide lonely people with the best cure for loneliness: direct in-person support," he stated. According to the World Health Organization, “loneliness affects one in six people worldwide”, having been “identified as a global public health concern”. Despite the sign, the study points to a positive side of this universe, noting that “AI technology has significant potential to support human beings in moments of psychological crisis, especially when human intervention is not available”.
